Researchers conducted a genomic survey of transcript ends in human B-lymphoblastoid cells from genetically distinct individuals to investigate the role of RNA 3'-end processing in regulatory variation. They found that transcript end positions did not occur randomly in untranslated regions, but rather preferentially flanked the locations of 3' regulatory elements, including microRNA sites. The usage of these transcript length forms and motifs varied across human individuals, and polymorphisms in polyadenylation signals and other 3' motifs were significant predictors of expression levels of the genes in which they lay. Independent single-gene experiments confirmed the effects of polyadenylation variants on steady-state expression of their respective genes, and validated the regulatory function of 3' cis-regulatory sequence elements that mediated expression of these distinct RNA length forms. Focusing on the immune regulator IRF5, the researchers established the effect of natural variation in RNA 3'-end processing on regulatory response to antigen stimulation. The study highlights the importance of two mechanisms at play in the genetics of 3'-end variation: the usage of distinct 3'-end processing signals and the effects of 3' sequence elements that determine transcript fate. The findings suggest that integrating observed 3'-end positions with inferred 3' regulatory motifs will be a critical tool in interpreting human genome variation.
A live attenuated simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) vaccine, SIVΔnef, has been shown to be highly effective in inducing protection against wild-type lentiviral challenge. However, the mechanisms underlying its protective efficacy are not well understood. Researchers used deep sequencing technology and comprehensive CD8 T cell epitope mapping to investigate the CD8 T cell response in SIVΔnef-vaccinated animals. They found that the initial CD8 T cell response in the acute phase of SIVΔnef infection targeted more variable epitopes, followed by widespread sequence evolution and viral escape. As a result, the CD8 T cell repertoire expanded to target highly conserved epitopes, known as anentropic specificity, and generated new responses to escaped epitope variants during the vaccination period. These findings correlated SIVΔnef-induced protection with expanded anentropic specificity and increased response depth. The study also demonstrated that epitope escape led to the generation of de novo CD8 T cell responses against novel epitopes and escape variants during chronic infection, and that these responses were maintained as central memory CD8 T cells, contributing to the increased cumulative breadth of the CD8 T cell response. The results suggest that SIVΔnef is a proof-of-concept vaccine that highlights the importance of anentropic specificity and repertoire depth in successful vaccine design. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms underlying the protective efficacy of SIVΔnef and has implications for the development of effective HIV/SIV vaccines.
Interleukin-1 (IL-1) plays a crucial role in coordinating the neutrophil response to Candida albicans infections in the oral mucosa. Research using a mouse model of oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) has shown that IL-1 receptor (IL-1R) signaling is essential for fungal control at the onset of infection. IL-1R signaling affects neutrophils in two ways: it regulates the recruitment of circulating neutrophils to the site of infection and the mobilization of newly generated neutrophils from the bone marrow. Mice deficient in IL-1R (Il1r1-/-) displayed impaired chemokine production at the site of infection and defective secretion of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) in the circulation in response to C. albicans.

The study found that endothelial cells are the primary source of G-CSF during OPC, and they respond to IL-1α released from keratinocytes in the infected tissue. This IL-1-dependent crosstalk between keratinocytes and endothelial cells was confirmed in vitro using a novel murine tongue-derived keratinocyte cell line and an established endothelial cell line. The data establish a new link between IL-1 and granulopoiesis in the context of fungal infection. Overall, the study identifies two complementary mechanisms by which IL-1 coordinates the neutrophil response in the oral mucosa, which is critical for preventing fungal growth and dissemination and protecting the host from disease.
Between 2000 and 2007, the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF) delivered over 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 600 million individuals through annual mass drug administration (MDA) of anti-filarial drugs in 48 of the 83 identified endemic countries. This significant achievement resulted in an estimated $21.8 billion in direct economic benefits over the lifetime of 31.4 million individuals treated during the first 8 years of the program. The economic benefits were calculated by quantifying the number of clinical manifestations averted and analyzing the savings associated with disease prevention, including direct treatment costs, indirect costs of lost labor, and costs to the health system to care for affected individuals.

The study found that the protection of nearly 3 million newborns and other individuals from acquiring lymphatic filariasis resulted in over $2.3 billion in economic benefits. Additionally, the halting of the progression of the disease in over 28 million individuals already infected with LF resulted in an associated lifetime economic benefit of approximately $19.5 billion. Furthermore, decreased patient services associated with reduced LF morbidity saved the health systems of endemic countries approximately $2.2 billion. The study concludes that MDA for LF offers significant economic benefits, and with favorable program implementation costs, the economic rate of return of the GPELF is extremely high, making it an excellent investment in global health.
Researchers have developed a new animal model to study Gaucher disease, a lysosomal storage disorder caused by mutations in the glucocerebrosidase (GBA) gene. The model, using medaka fish (Oryzias latipes), displays characteristics similar to the neuronopathic form of Gaucher disease in humans, including infiltration of Gaucher cell-like cells into the brain, progressive neuronal loss, and microgliosis. Detailed analysis revealed lysosomal abnormalities in neurons and accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) in axonal swellings containing autophagosomes. The study found that disrupting α-syn did not improve the lifespan, formation of axonal swellings, neuronal loss, or neuroinflammation in the GBA-deficient medaka. This suggests that α-syn may not play a significant role in the pathogenesis of neuronopathic Gaucher disease. Gaucher disease is associated with an increased risk of developing Parkinson's disease (PD), and mutations in the GBA gene have been linked to α-syn accumulation in PD patients. The study provides new insights into the pathological mechanisms of α-syn accumulation caused by GCase deficiency and highlights the potential importance of axonal transport of α-syn in the mechanisms leading to PD. The medaka model may serve as a valuable tool for further research into the pathogenesis of neuronopathic Gaucher disease and the development of novel therapies.
Researchers studied how the immune system responds to Listeria monocytogenes, a type of bacteria that can live inside host cells. They found that when L. monocytogenes is contained within a phagosome, a type of cellular compartment, it can suppress the immune system's ability to mount a strong response against it. This suppression is not just due to inefficient antigen presentation, but rather a direct effect on the adaptive immune response. Specifically, the presence of phagosome-confined L. monocytogenes limited the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and led to the rapid production of IL-10, a cytokine that can suppress the immune response. As a result, the immune system's ability to generate protective CD8 T cells, a type of immune cell that plays a key role in fighting off infections, was impaired.

The researchers also found that co-infection with both phagosome-confined and cytosolic L. monocytogenes prevented the generation of acquired immunity and limited the expansion of antigen-specific T cells. However, blocking the IL-10 receptor or the absence of MyD88, a protein involved in the immune response, restored protective immunity. These findings suggest that the presence of microbes within a phagosome can directly impact the innate and adaptive immune response by antagonizing the signaling pathways necessary for inflammation and the generation of protective CD8 T cells. This has significant implications for understanding how microbes interact with the immune system and how to control their pathogenic effects.
Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a leading cause of blindness worldwide, affecting approximately 60 million people. Genome-wide association studies have previously identified a significant association between POAG and the SIX6 locus, which plays a role in ocular development and optic nerve morphology. Researchers sequenced the SIX6 coding and regulatory regions in 262 POAG cases and 256 controls, identifying six nonsynonymous coding variants, including five rare and one common variant, Asn141His (rs33912345), which was significantly associated with POAG.

The variants were tested in an in vivo Danio rerio (zebrafish) complementation assay to evaluate ocular metrics such as eye size and optic nerve structure. The results showed that five variants, primarily found in POAG cases, were hypomorphic or null, while the sixth variant, found only in controls, was benign. One variant in the SIX6 enhancer increased expression of SIX6 and disrupted its regulation.

Furthermore, the study found a clinical feature in POAG patients that appears to be dependent on SIX6 genotype: patients who are homozygous for the SIX6 risk allele (His141) have a statistically thinner retinal nerve fiber layer than patients homozygous for the SIX6 non-risk allele (Asn141). The results suggest that SIX6 risk variants disrupt the development of the neural retina, leading to a reduced number of retinal ganglion cells, thereby increasing the risk of glaucoma-associated vision loss.
Researchers have identified a genetic switch, known as the flagellar switch, that controls the production of flagella and toxins in the human intestinal pathogen Clostridium difficile. This switch, located upstream of the flgB operon, is a 154-base pair invertible sequence flanked by 21-base pair inverted repeats. The orientation of the flagellar switch determines whether the bacteria express flagellum and toxin genes, produce flagella, and secrete toxins. When the switch is in the "flg phase ON" orientation, bacteria express flagellar and toxin genes, produce flagella, and secrete toxins. In contrast, when the switch is in the "flg phase OFF" orientation, bacteria are attenuated for flagellar and toxin gene expression, are aflagellate, and show decreased toxin secretion. The orientation of the flagellar switch is reversible during growth in vitro. The researchers found that the tyrosine recombinase RecV, which catalyzes inversion at the cwpV switch, is also responsible for inversion at the flagellar switch in both directions. This phase variable flagellar motility and toxin production suggests that these important virulence factors have both advantageous and detrimental effects during the course of infection. The flagellar switch affects transcription of the toxin genes by way of σD, impacting the production of the glucosylating toxins and the cytotoxicity of C. difficile.
Researchers investigated the spore differentiation pathway in Clostridium difficile, an intestinal pathogen that relies on endospore formation for its infectious cycle. They studied the function and regulation of the sporulation sigma factors, which control gene expression during endospore development. The study found that while the main periods of activity of the sigma factors are conserved, there are significant deviations from the well-studied model organism Bacillus subtilis. Specifically, the activity of σE is partially independent of σF, σG activity is not dependent on σE, and σK activity does not require σG. Additionally, σK is not strictly required for heat-resistant spore formation. These findings indicate reduced temporal segregation between the activities of the early and late sigma factors, and reduced requirement for the σF-to-σE, σE-to-σG, and σG-to-σK cell-cell signaling pathways. Despite these differences, the study supports the view that the top level of the endosporulation network is conserved in evolution, with the sigma factors acting as key regulators of the pathway. The results also suggest that differences in the function and period of activity of the sporulation sigma factors in other Clostridial species may be related to the coordination of solventogenesis, toxin production, or other functions with sporulation.
Researchers have developed a simplified framework to model the behavior of proteins with multiple phosphorylation sites, known as allosteric multisite proteins. This framework uses a single auxiliary variable to replicate the steady-state behavior of more complex models, such as the Monod-Wyman-Changeux allosteric model. The model assumes that the activation of the protein by its individual sites is concerted and redundant, resulting in optimal ultrasensitivity. This simplification makes the framework useful for modeling and analyzing biochemical systems in practical applications, where multiple multisite proteins interact simultaneously.

The researchers applied this framework to a newly discovered checkpoint signaling pathway in budding yeast, which measures cell growth by monitoring signals generated at sites of plasma membrane growth. They showed that the known components of this pathway can form a robust hysteretic switch, incorporating a signal proportional to bud growth or size, a mechanism to read the signal, and an all-or-none response triggered when the signal reaches a threshold. The framework can also be extended to other types of multisite modifications, such as ligand binding, transcription factor regulation, and ubiquitination.

The model assumes that the protein substrate is phosphorylated by a kinase at possible sites and dephosphorylated by a phosphatase, and that the system is nonsequential, with different phosphoforms of the protein. The number of sites is thought to be relatively large, and the model becomes increasingly precise as the number of sites increases, with good estimates already for around four or more sites.
Researchers used a combination of experimental work and mathematical models to study the quorum sensing (QS) system in E. coli bacteria. Quorum sensing is a mechanism that allows bacteria to communicate with each other and coordinate their behavior. The study focused on the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) QS system, which involves a complex network of regulatory interactions. By separating the network into sub-networks and analyzing each module separately, the researchers identified a new negative feedback interaction that plays a crucial role in the system. They also discovered that the LsrR regulator is a key component of the QS "switch" in E. coli, which is normally masked by interfering regulatory loops. A simple mathematical model was developed to understand the interplay among regulatory sub-structures and their contributions to the overall native functioning network. This "bottom-up" approach allowed the researchers to unravel the complex QS network architecture and shed light on other regulatory pathways within the metabolic networks of bacterial cells. The study's findings can be used to guide the development of new biotechnological applications that incorporate quorum sensing switches. The researchers were able to simulate both the intact network and its sub-systems using their proposed network architecture, providing a mechanistic understanding of the LsrR-mediated genetic "switch" of E. coli QS circuitry. This study demonstrates the effectiveness of using a bottom-up approach to analyze complex biological networks, especially when positive and negative regulations exist within the network architecture.
A study was conducted in rural Gabon to investigate the effect of schistosomiasis, caused by the parasite Schistosoma haematobium, on the prevalence and incidence of Plasmodium falciparum infection in school-age children. The study found that schistosomiasis tends to increase the risk of Plasmodium infection, and when combined with soil-transmitted helminths (STH), such as Trichuris trichiura or hookworm, the risk is significantly increased. The study also found that the incidence of malaria was higher in children infected with Schistosoma haematobium compared to those who were not infected, with a significant delay in the time to the first malaria event in children aged 6-10 years. The study suggests that STH enhance the risk of P. falciparum infection in schistosomiasis-positive children, and that schistosomiasis enhances susceptibility to developing malaria in young children but not in older children. The study's findings have implications for malaria control programs in areas where both schistosomiasis and malaria are endemic, and suggest that controlling STH and schistosomiasis could be an additional tool for reducing malaria incidence.
Researchers investigated the role of the transcription factor IRF-5 in regulating CD8+ T cell responses during Leishmania donovani infection. They found that IRF-5-induced inflammation limits CD8+ T cell expansion and induces hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1α) in dendritic cells. HIF-1α impairs dendritic cell functions, leading to a decrease in IL-12 expression and an increase in IL-10 expression. This results in a higher frequency of short-lived effector CD8+ T cells and reduced CD8+ T cell expansion. Mice with targeted depletion of HIF-1α in dendritic cells showed enhanced CD8+ T cell expansion and reduced parasite burden, suggesting that HIF-1α induction is an immune-evasive mechanism adopted by Leishmania parasites to establish persistent infections. The study suggests that IRF-5-mediated inflammation at early stages of infection plays a detrimental role in the development of protective CD8+ T cell responses. The findings indicate that HIF-1α induction in dendritic cells is a key mechanism by which Leishmania parasites evade the host immune response and establish chronic infection.
Researchers conducted a meta-analysis to identify risk factors for adverse prognosis and death in American visceral leishmaniasis (VL), a serious public health problem in Latin America. They analyzed 14 studies that met the inclusion criteria and examined the methodological quality of the studies using a developed tool. The analysis identified several strong predictors of unfavorable outcomes, including jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age under 5 and over 40-50 years, severe neutropenia, dyspnea, and bacterial infections. Edema and low hemoglobin concentration were also associated with poor outcomes.

The study found that Leishmania-HIV coinfection was a significant prognostic factor for adverse evolution of VL, with coinfected individuals having a higher risk of poor prognosis. The analysis also highlighted the importance of platelet transfusion in VL patients with platelet counts below 10,000 platelets/mm3, as recommended by the Ministry of Health of Brazil.

The study's findings suggest that the lack of reduction in fatality rates of VL in Brazil can be attributed to limitations in therapy, delayed diagnosis, and inadequate management of high-risk patients. The identification of prognostic factors associated with VL can be a valuable tool for clinical practice, enabling healthcare providers to recognize and manage patients at higher risk of unfavorable outcomes. The study emphasizes the need for the development of externally validated prognostic models to improve the management of VL patients.
Researchers in Algeria investigated the susceptibility of Leishmania parasites to antimony, a common treatment for visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis, over a 30-year period. The study analyzed 106 isolates from humans, dogs, rodents, and phlebotomines collected between 1976 and 2013 in Algeria, as well as 18 isolates from dogs in France. The researchers determined the 50% inhibitory concentrations (IC50) of potassium antimony tartrate (Sb(III)) and sodium stibogluconate (Sb(V)) in promastigotes and intramacrophage amastigotes, respectively. The epidemiological cutoff (ECOFF) values were established to differentiate between Leishmania species causing cutaneous or visceral leishmaniasis that were susceptible (S+) or insusceptible (S-) to the trivalent form of antimony. The results showed a trend of increasing antimony susceptibility in visceral leishmaniasis (VL) isolates during the 30-year period, whereas an increase in the frequency of S- phenotypes in cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) isolates was observed. The emergence of S- phenotypes correlated with the inclusion of L. killicki (syn: L. tropica) isolates that cause cutaneous leishmaniasis and have emerged in Algeria during the last decade. The study highlights the need for an effective methodology to determine the antimony susceptibility status of Leishmania isolates to detect the emergence of and prevent the dissemination of drug-resistant strains. The findings provide insight into the spatiotemporal dynamics of Leishmania antimony susceptibility in Algeria and emphasize the importance of preserving the therapeutic efficiency of antimonials to cure leishmaniasis.
Researchers investigated the link between acute infectious gastroenteritis and the development of Crohn's disease (CD), a chronic inflammatory condition. They developed two new models to study the comorbidity of acute gastroenteritis caused by Salmonella Typhimurium or Citrobacter rodentium in mice colonized with adherent-invasive Escherichia coli (AIEC), a bacterial pathobiont linked to CD. The study found that disease activity in the post-infectious period after gastroenteritis is driven by the tissue-associated expansion of the resident AIEC pathobiont, leading to an increase in immunopathology, barrier defects, and delays in mucosal restitution following pathogen clearance. This expansion required AIEC resistance to host defense peptides and a fulminant inflammatory response to the enteric pathogen. The results suggest that individuals colonized by AIEC at the time of acute infectious gastroenteritis may be at greater risk for CD onset. The study also identified AIEC as a tractable disease modifier, a finding that could be exploited in the development of therapeutic interventions following infectious gastroenteritis in at-risk individuals. The researchers used two models to study the comorbidity of acute infectious gastroenteritis in hosts colonized by an AIEC pathobiont, showing that AIEC-colonized mice that develop infectious gastroenteritis have a worsened outcome compared to AIEC-naïve animals exposed to the same infection stimuli.
Researchers have identified a gene called Lachesis (LIS) that plays a crucial role in determining the fate of cells in the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis, a flowering plant. The female gametophyte contains two gametic cells, the egg cell and the central cell, as well as five accessory cells, all of which are essential for fertilization. However, the mechanisms that control the formation of accessory versus gametic cell fate were previously unknown.

The researchers isolated a mutant called lachesis (lis) that forms supernumerary egg cells, indicating that LIS is involved in a mechanism that prevents accessory cells from adopting gametic cell fate. The temporal and spatial pattern of LIS expression suggests that this mechanism is generated in gametic cells. LIS is homologous to the yeast splicing factor PRP4, indicating that components of the splice apparatus participate in cell fate decisions.

The lis mutant phenotype reveals two levels of cell fate regulation: one between gametic and accessory cells, and one between egg and central cell. The late initiation of cell-specific marker genes indicates that in Arabidopsis, distinct cell fates are only manifested after cellularization. The researchers found that in lis-1 mutant gametophytes, accessory cells differentiate gametic cell fate, and the gametic central cell in lis-1 gametophytes adopts egg cell fate, suggesting that a further, LIS-dependent mechanism suppresses egg cell fate in the central cell.
Researchers conducted a qualitative study in a rural highland Ethiopian community to understand the barriers to wearing shoes, which is crucial for preventing Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs). The study used the PRECEDE-PROCEED model to assess social, behavioral, environmental, educational, and ecological factors influencing shoe use among children. The study involved 242 respondents through focus groups, semi-structured interviews, and extended case studies. The results showed that shoe-wearing norms are changing, with going barefoot becoming increasingly seen as "shameful." However, many practical and social barriers prevent people from wearing shoes, including limited financial resources, which make it difficult to purchase and maintain shoes. As a result, shoes are often reserved for special occasions and may not be provided for children until they reach a certain age.

The study identified several barriers to shoe wearing that are relevant to a range of NTDs, including podoconiosis, a disease triggered by exposure to irritant soils in the tropical highlands. These barriers include financial constraints, poor suitability of shoes for daily activities, and low risk perception. The study also found that podoconiosis patients face additional barriers, such as difficulty finding large enough sizes and fear of stigma and labeling. The findings suggest that targeting individuals' beliefs and attitudes about shoe wearing, as well as addressing underlying structural barriers related to poverty, can be effective in promoting consistent use of shoes and preventing NTDs.
The pseudorabies virus (PRV) Us9 protein plays a crucial role in targeting viral capsids and glycoproteins to axons of dissociated sympathetic neurons. Research has shown that Us9 null mutants are defective in anterograde transmission of infection in vivo. To understand how Us9 promotes axonal sorting of viral proteins, scientists investigated the association of Us9 with lipid rafts on the surface of infected cells. Lipid rafts are microdomains that facilitate the sorting and trafficking of proteins within cells.

The study found that Us9 is associated with lipid rafts and that this association is critical for Us9-mediated sorting of viral structural proteins. In non-polarized and polarized PC12 cells, a rat pheochromocytoma cell line, Us9 was highly enriched in detergent-resistant membranes (DRMs). Reducing the affinity of Us9 for lipid rafts inhibited anterograde transmission of infection from sympathetic neurons to epithelial cells in vitro. These findings suggest that association of Us9 with lipid rafts is essential for efficient targeting of structural proteins to axons and directional spread of PRV from pre-synaptic to post-synaptic neurons and cells of the mammalian nervous system.

The study also demonstrated that Us9 is responsible for the axonal sorting of viral capsids and glycoproteins gB, gC, and gE, and that this sorting is critical for anterograde neuron-to-cell and neuron-to-neuron spread of the virus. Overall, the research provides new insights into the mechanisms of anterograde transport of alpha herpesviruses in the mammalian nervous system and highlights the importance of Us9 in targeting viral proteins to axons.
Research has shown that genetically identical cells of the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae exhibit phenotypic variation in growth rate and stress tolerance, even under constant and benign conditions. This phenomenon, known as nongenetic heterogeneity, has significant implications for understanding the behavior of cells in tumors and microbial infections. The study aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanism underlying nongenetic heterogeneity in yeast-cell growth and acute stress tolerance. Using genetic and chemical perturbations, combined with high-throughput single-cell assays, the researchers found that heterogeneity in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels, acting through the Ras/cAMP/protein kinase A (PKA) pathway and its target transcription factors Msn2 and Msn4, underlies this nongenetic heterogeneity. Lower cAMP levels correspond to slower growth, and an endogenous reporter of this pathway's activity correlates with growth in individual cells. The paralogs Msn2 and Msn4 differ in their roles in nongenetic heterogeneity, with Msn2 being required for heterogeneity in expression of Tsl1, a subunit of trehalose synthase that contributes to acute-stress tolerance. Perturbing nongenetic heterogeneity by mutating genes in this pathway or by culturing wild-type cells with the cell-permeable cAMP analog 8-bromo-cAMP or the PKA inhibitor H89 significantly impacts survival of acute heat stress. The results suggest that the Ras/cAMP/PKA pathway, acting through Msn2 and Msn4, underlies nongenetic heterogeneity in yeast-cell growth and stress tolerance.
Researchers analyzed the genetic diversity of the Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) during an outbreak in the Caribbean islands of Guadeloupe and Martinique in 2013-2014. The study used deep-sequencing technologies to examine the viral genetic diversity present in infected individuals and understand how the virus may have evolved during the outbreak. The analysis revealed changes in the consensus sequence and a diverse range of minority variants present at various levels in the population. Additionally, the study found that the overall diversity of the virus was reduced after single passages in cell lines. An infectious clone of the virus was constructed, and a novel 3' untranslated region (UTR) structure was identified, which led to increased replication in insect cells. This new UTR structure was not previously found in nature. The study also identified novel variants present in infected individuals, suggesting that CHIKV has rapidly evolved in a short period of time once it entered the naïve population. The findings highlight the need for continued viral diversity surveillance over time to understand the evolutionary potential of CHIKV. The study provides an in-depth look at the minority variants present during the ongoing CHIKV epidemic, identifying novel variants and structural elements. The results were consistent with previous studies, placing the viruses in the Asian Lineage of CHIKV and clustering with the St. Martin strain CNR20236.
Researchers have identified a previously unannotated gene, UBTOR/KIAA1024, which plays a crucial role in regulating cell growth and the mTOR signaling pathway. mTOR signaling is involved in various human diseases, including cancer. The study found that reducing UBTOR function in cultured hippocampal neurons and PC12 cells promotes neurite outgrowth and cell growth. Conversely, overexpressing UBTOR suppresses colony formation in cancer cell lines. Mechanistic studies revealed that UBTOR stabilizes DEPTOR, a component of the mTOR complex, to inhibit mTOR signaling. In zebrafish models, disrupting the UBTOR gene upregulates mTOR signaling and promotes tumor formation induced by the HRAS G12V mutation. Furthermore, UBTOR depletion promotes tumor growth and mTOR signaling in a xenograft mouse model. These findings demonstrate that UBTOR regulates cell growth and neoplasia through mTOR signaling. The study also showed that UBTOR interacts with DEPTOR and mTOR complexes, and that NGF treatment upregulates UBTOR expression, which may help keep mTOR signaling activity in check. Overall, the results suggest that UBTOR is a functional player in regulating cell growth and mTOR signaling, and its dysregulation may contribute to neoplasia.
Researchers have created a comprehensive map of protein complexes in the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei, which causes human African trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness. This parasite is highly diverged from well-studied eukaryotes, making it challenging to understand its biology and pathogenesis. To address this, the researchers used biochemical fractionation to systematically investigate the co-complex interactions of over 3,300 protein groups in the procyclic life stage of T. brucei. Their analysis led to the identification of 128 high-confidence complexes, encompassing 716 protein groups, including 635 previously uncharacterized proteins. These complexes correlated well with known pathways and proteins co-expressed across the T. brucei life cycle, providing potential functions for a large number of uncharacterized proteins. The researchers validated the functions of several novel proteins associated with the RNA-editing machinery, including a candidate involved in the mitochondrial post-transcriptional regulation of T. brucei. This protein complex map provides an unprecedented view of T. brucei and serves as a reliable resource for further characterization of trypanosomatid proteins. The study presents the largest proteomics-based interaction map of trypanosomatid parasites to date, offering a useful resource for formulating new biological hypotheses and experimental leads.
Lymph nodes (LNs) are a common site of extrapulmonary Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection, particularly in the thoracic region. However, the dynamics of Mtb infection in LNs and its impact on LN structure and function are not well understood. Researchers studied thoracic LNs in Mtb-infected cynomolgus and rhesus macaques using PET CT scans, bacterial burden analysis, and immune function assessment. The study found that LNs in Mtb-infected macaques showed increased metabolic activity early during infection, and at necropsy, almost all FDG-avid LNs contained viable Mtb or persistent Mtb DNA. The researchers discovered that Mtb grows to the same level in LNs of both macaque species, but cynomolgus macaque LNs were better able to control the infection compared to rhesus macaque LNs. In contrast to lung granulomas, LNs were found to be poor at killing Mtb, even with drug treatment. Granulomas that form in LNs disrupt their structure, pushing out T cells and B cells, introducing large numbers of macrophages that can serve as niches for Mtb, and destroying normal vasculature. The study suggests that LNs are not only sites of antigen presentation and immune activation during infection but also serve as important sites for the persistence of significant numbers of Mtb bacilli.
A large collection of 47 nematode-infecting microsporidia has been isolated and cultured from wild nematodes, providing new insights into the diversity and ubiquity of microsporidian infections in nematodes. The microsporidian Nematocida parisii was found to be the most common pathogen infecting Caenorhabditis elegans in the wild, and six new species in the Nematocida genus were identified. Additionally, two new subclades, Enteropsectra and Pancytospora, were discovered, which are genetically distinct from Nematocida and belong to the main clade of microsporidia that includes human pathogens. These microsporidia are horizontally transmitted and primarily infect intestinal cells, except for Pancytospora epiphaga, which replicates in the epidermis of its Caenorhabditis host. At the subcellular level, spores of Enteropsectra exhibit a characteristic apical distribution and exit via budding off the plasma membrane, unlike Nematocida, which exits via exocytosis. The host specificity of these microsporidia varies, with some species infecting multiple nematode species, while others exhibit narrow host specificity. Furthermore, one microsporidian species, Nematocida ausubeli, was found to have evolved mechanisms to prevent the induction of a host response in C. elegans. This collection of microsporidia provides a rich resource for investigating host-parasite coevolution in tractable nematode hosts and highlights the diversity and ubiquity of microsporidian infections in nematodes.
Chemokine receptors, a subclass of G protein-coupled receptors, play crucial roles in the human immune system and are involved in cancer metastasis and HIV infection. Recent studies have shown that homo- and heterodimers or higher-order oligomers of chemokine receptors modulate receptor function. However, structural information about homo- and heterodimers formed by chemokine receptors and their interaction with cholesterol is limited. This study used molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the spontaneous homo- and heterodimerization of chemokine receptors CXCR4, CCR5, and CCR2. The results reveal that the closely related CC chemokine receptors CCR5 and CCR2 share common features with regard to dimerization and interactions with cholesterol, which differ from the previously reported characteristics of CXCR4. Cholesterol was found to modulate the homodimer interfaces of CC chemokine receptors in a subtype-specific manner. The study also provides the first structural information about chemokine receptor heterodimers and elucidates the role of cholesterol in differentiating between the heterodimerization of CXCR4 and the CC chemokine receptors. The findings suggest that cholesterol can increase the dynamic range and versatility of associations of closely related transmembrane receptors. The study provides a comprehensive structural overview of the complex interaction network between chemokine receptors and indicates how heterodimerization and interaction with the membrane environment diversifies the function of closely related G protein-coupled receptors.
Systemic leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the Leishmania parasite, has been found to present with a wider range of symptoms than previously thought. In addition to the classical form, characterized by prolonged fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and wasting, researchers have identified a sub-clinical form and an atypical form. The atypical form presents with depressed immunity, masquerading as a condition where the immune system is non-functional, leading to recurrent secondary infections and a variety of clinical signs and symptoms. This form was discovered in 19.4% of 160 patients referred to a specialized laboratory for immune function evaluation, despite having normal laboratory profiles. The patients with atypical systemic leishmaniasis exhibited dysfunctional macrophages laden with Leishmania parasites. This finding suggests that systemic leishmaniasis is more common than previously diagnosed and is not limited to the pediatric age group, as adults were also affected. The researchers recommend considering atypical systemic leishmaniasis in patients with unexplained depressed immunity and no obvious immunologic defect. The discovery of this atypical form expands the clinical picture of systemic leishmaniasis, which was previously thought to present with a well-defined set of symptoms.
Researchers have analyzed millions of mutations and polymorphisms in human populations to identify potential predictors of disease, drug reactions, microbial infections, and age-related conditions. However, predicting the phenotypic consequences of a sequence variant is a complex task. To address this challenge, the study investigated the potential of variants that occur at homologous positions within paralogous human proteins as a means of identifying polymorphisms with likely phenotypic consequences. A dataset of known disease-causing variants from OMIM and HGMD was used to identify and characterize pairs of sequence variants that occur at homologous positions within paralogous human proteins. The results demonstrate that the locations of variants are correlated in paralogous proteins, and if one member of a variant-pair is disease-causing, its partner is likely to be disease-causing as well. This finding suggests that information about variant-pairs can be used to identify potentially disease-causing variants, extend existing procedures for polymorphism prioritization, and provide a suite of candidates for further diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. The study also shows that paralogous disease genes and their variant-pairs can be used for hypothesis generation and as points of departure for further clinical research, and that extending this procedure to include paralogs of known disease genes could identify new disease gene candidates and uncharacterized variants with phenotypic consequences.
Researchers studied the genetic makeup of the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum in patients with severe and uncomplicated malaria. They used a technique called RNA sequencing to analyze the parasite's gene expression in 44 isolates from Papuan patients. The results showed that parasites causing severe malaria had altered gene expression compared to those causing uncomplicated malaria. Specifically, they found that severe malaria parasites had decreased glycolysis, altered chromatin structure, and reduced expression of surface antigens called PfEMP1. PfEMP1s are major targets of protective immunity, and their reduced expression may explain why immunity to severe malaria is acquired more rapidly than immunity to uncomplicated malaria.

The study also identified novel associations between disease severity and PfEMP1 transcripts, domains, and smaller sequence segments. This suggests that the parasite adapts to or is selected by the host environment in severe malaria. The researchers found that the parasites causing severe malaria had down-regulated genes involved in PfEMP1 surface expression, including skeleton-binding protein 1, which is directly involved in PfEMP1 surface expression. This is consistent with previous studies showing that severe malaria patients have lower levels of antibodies to PfEMP1 and recognize fewer PfEMP1s than uncomplicated malaria patients.

The findings of this study will inform efforts to identify vaccine targets for severe malaria and provide insights into how the parasite adapts to or is selected by the host environment in severe malaria.
Researchers have explored the use of adeno-associated virus (AAV) vectors to deliver anti-SIV monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) to rhesus monkeys as a potential approach to prevent HIV-1 infection. In this study, the AAV vector was used to deliver the anti-SIV mAb 5L7 IgG1 to rhesus monkeys, resulting in persisting levels of the delivered mAb ranging from 1-270 μg/ml. However, host antibody responses to the delivered mAb were observed in 9 of the 12 monkeys, which limited the concentration of delivered mAb that could be achieved.

Despite the absence of detectable neutralizing activity against the challenge virus, the six monkeys in the AAV-5L7 IgG1 mAb group showed significant protective effects against SIVmac239 challenge. These effects included lowering of viral load at peak height, lowering of viral load at set point, and delay in the time to peak viral load from the time of infectious virus exposure. Notably, one monkey with the highest level of delivered 5L7 mAb completely resisted six successive SIVmac239 challenges, including a final challenge with a dose of 10 i.v. infectious units.

The study demonstrates the continued promise of this approach for the prevention of HIV-1 infection. However, the problem of anti-antibody responses to the delivered mAb will need to be understood and overcome for this approach to be effectively realized. The findings suggest that AAV-mediated delivery of mAbs may be a viable strategy for preventing HIV-1 infection, but further research is needed to address the issue of anti-antibody responses.
Researchers have challenged the long-held assumption that protein molecules respond linearly to thermal noise or structural perturbations, such as ligand binding or detachment. This assumption is commonly used in studies of protein dynamics, where conformational motions are analyzed in terms of normal modes and thermal fluctuations are interpreted as the excitation of these modes. A team of scientists investigated the conformational relaxation properties of two motor proteins, myosin V and kinesin KIF1A, using a coarse-grained elastic network approximation. They found that the linearity assumption is deficient for ligand-induced conformational motions and can even be violated for characteristic thermal fluctuations. In particular, the normal mode description fails completely in describing functional mechanochemical motions in KIF1A. The study suggests that important assumptions of the theory of protein dynamics may need to be reconsidered, as neither a single normal mode nor a superposition of such modes yields an approximation of strongly nonlinear dynamics. Despite the nonlinearity, the researchers found well-defined conformational relaxation paths in both motor proteins, which are robust against perturbations. These findings indicate that protein dynamics may be more complex than previously thought and highlight the need for a more nuanced understanding of protein behavior.
Researchers have investigated the molecular mechanisms and functional relevance of crosstalk between different clathrin-independent endocytic pathways. They found that caveolins and cavins, crucial components of caveolae, are independently acting negative regulators of clathrin-independent endocytosis. Specifically, Cavin-1 and Cavin-3, but not Cavin-2 or Cavin-4, inhibit the clathrin-independent carriers/GPI-AP enriched early endosomal compartment (CLIC/GEEC) endocytic pathway in a process independent of caveola formation. Caveolin-1 (CAV1) and CAV3 also inhibit the CLIC/GEEC pathway upon over-expression. Expression of caveolar protein leads to a reduction in the formation of early CLIC/GEEC carriers, as detected by quantitative electron microscopy analysis. The CLIC/GEEC pathway is upregulated in cells lacking CAV1/Cavin-1 or with reduced expression of Cavin-1 and Cavin-3. Inhibition by caveolins can be mimicked by the isolated caveolin scaffolding domain and is associated with perturbed diffusion of lipid microdomain components. In the absence of cavins, CAV1 is itself endocytosed preferentially through the CLIC/GEEC pathway, but the pathway loses polarization and sorting attributes with consequences for membrane dynamics and endocytic polarization in migrating cells and adult muscle tissue. Noncaveolar Cavin-1 can act as a modulator for the activity of the key regulator of the CLIC/GEEC pathway, Cdc42. This work provides new insights into the regulation of noncaveolar clathrin-independent endocytosis by specific caveolar proteins, illustrating multiple levels of crosstalk between these pathways.
Researchers have identified a subset of Receiver (REC) domains, known as Aspartate-Less Receiver (ALR) domains, which lack the conserved aspartate (Asp) residue typically phosphorylated by sensory histidine kinases in two-component signaling systems. These systems are crucial for sensing and responding to environmental stimuli in bacteria, Archaea, and plants. The study found that ALR domains are surprisingly common, comprising approximately 4% of all REC domains, and are enriched when attached to rare effector outputs. Analysis of ALR atomic structures, combined with structural, biochemical, and genetic data, suggests that these domains have reorganized their active pockets to take on a constitutive regulatory role or accommodate input signals other than Asp phosphorylation, while retaining canonical post-phosphorylation mechanisms and dimeric interfaces. The study also found that some ALR domains have diversified to accommodate signaling inputs from small molecules, such as antibiotics, and Ser-Thr phosphorylation through bacterial eukaryotic-like Ser-Thr kinases and their cognate PP2C phosphatases, which regulate crucial cell envelope-related functions and virulence in many microbes. The researchers identified 74,816 unique REC-containing proteins, 2,976 of which were missing or had substitutions at the conserved Asp position, and renamed this subset of REC-type sequences Aspartate-Less Receivers (ALRs). The study defines ALRs as an atypical REC subclass and provides insights into shared mechanisms of activation between ALR and REC domains.
Researchers have developed a new type of oncolytic herpes simplex virus (oHSV) that targets cancer cells by retargeting to specific receptors, such as HER2, which is overexpressed in various cancers. Unlike traditional oHSVs, which are attenuated or over-attenuated due to deletions or mutations, these new viruses are fully virulent in targeted cancer cells while sparing other cells in the tumor. The study investigated the efficacy and safety of a HER2-retargeted, fully virulent oHSV armed with IL-12 (R-115) in immunocompetent mice. The results showed that both the unarmed R-LM113 and the IL-12-armed R-115 inhibited the growth of primary HER2-expressing tumors, with R-115 being more efficacious. Notably, mice that survived the primary treated tumors were protected from the growth of contralateral untreated tumors, indicating an abscopal immunotherapeutic effect. Analysis of the local response revealed that R-115 unleashed an immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment, inducing immunomodulatory cytokines and promoting Th1 polarization. Tumor-infiltrating cells, such as CD4+ and CD335+ cells, were increased in all responder mice, while CD8+, Foxp3+, and CD141+ cells were increased and CD11b+ cells were decreased preferentially in R-115-treated mice. The study demonstrated a durable response, including a breakage of tolerance towards both HER2 and wild-type tumor cells, and underscored a systemic immunotherapeutic vaccine response.
A recent study investigated the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by different HIV vaccine vectors to HIV infection. The study compared the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by adenovirus 5 (Ad5) and canarypox viral vector (ALVAC) to HIV. The results showed that Ad5-specific CD4 T cells were readily susceptible to HIV, while ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells were substantially less susceptible to both R5 and X4 HIV in vitro. The lower susceptibility of ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells was associated with reduced surface expression of HIV entry co-receptors CCR5 and CXCR4 on these cells. Phenotypic analysis revealed that ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells displayed a strong Th1 phenotype, producing higher levels of IFN-γ and CCL4 (MIP-β) but little IL-17. The study also found that ALVAC and Ad5 vectors induced distinct profiles of vector-specific CD8 vs. CD4 T-cell proliferative responses in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC). Depletion of ALVAC-induced CD8 T cells in PBMC led to a modest increase in HIV infection of vector-specific CD4 T cells, suggesting a role of ALVAC-specific CD8 T cells in protecting ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells from HIV. The study highlights the importance of evaluating anti-vector responses in HIV vaccination and suggests that the choice of vaccine vector may impact the susceptibility of CD4 T cells to HIV infection.
A theoretical population genetic analysis was conducted to investigate the evolution of X inactivation strategies in therian mammals. X inactivation is the process by which one of the two X chromosomes in female somatic cells is transcriptionally silenced. The study found that a single interaction between allelic dominance and sex-differential selection can select for a range of X inactivation strategies, including unequal rates of inactivation between maternally and paternally inherited X chromosomes. Random X inactivation (RXI), which equalizes expression of maternally and paternally inherited alleles, is favored over strict paternally inherited X inactivation (PXI) as long as alleles deleterious to female fitness are sufficiently recessive. However, the criteria for RXI evolution are more restrictive when fitness variation is sexually antagonistic, meaning alleles deleterious to females are beneficial to males. The study also found that evolutionary transitions from PXI to RXI generally increase mean relative female fitness at the expense of decreased male fitness. The results provide a theoretical framework for predicting and interpreting the evolution of chromosome-wide expression of X-linked genes. The study suggests that species-specific properties of mutation and genetic variation can predictably affect patterns of selection for different X inactivation strategies, and that sex-differential selection can influence the relative transmission probabilities of female-deleterious alleles between maternally and paternally derived X chromosomes.
Researchers investigated the antiviral potential of the human zinc-finger antiviral protein (ZAP) against three flaviviruses: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIKV). They found that overexpression of ZAP blocked JEV infection, while depletion of endogenous ZAP enhanced JEV replication. In contrast, DENV and ZIKV were not affected by ZAP overexpression. ZAP hampered JEV translation and targeted viral RNA for 3'-5' RNA exosome-mediated degradation. The zinc-finger motifs of ZAP were essential for RNA targeting and anti-JEV activity. JEV 3'-UTR, particularly in the region with dumbbell structures and high content of CG dinucleotide, was mapped to bind ZAP and confer sensitivity to ZAP. The study identified JEV as the first ZAP-sensitive flavivirus. ZAP may act as an intrinsic antiviral factor through specific RNA binding to fight against JEV infection. The researchers also found that the zinc-finger motifs of ZAP were essential for RNA targeting and antiviral activity against JEV infection. The study provides insight into the antiviral mechanism of ZAP against viral RNA without a 3'-poly(A) tail, suggesting that 3'-5' RNA degradation by the exosome complex is involved in the antiviral mechanism of ZAP against JEV infection.
Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is a highly pathogenic virus that causes severe disease in humans and animals, particularly in Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Researchers investigated the host response to RVFV infection in mice to understand the pathogenesis of the virus. Two strains of RVFV, wild-type ZH501 and live-attenuated vaccine strain MP-12, were used to infect C57BL/6 mice. The study found that mice infected with MP-12 survived the infection with minimal clinical disease and a low cytokine response, whereas ZH501 infection was lethal, causing lymphopenia, platelet depletion, and a strong systemic cytokine response. The liver was found to be a primary target of RVFV infection, with significant clinical and histological evidence of liver necrosis and hepatitis. However, a pro-inflammatory response was not observed in the liver, but rather a chemokine response indicating the infiltration of immunoreactive cells. In contrast, the brain showed a significant chemokine and pro-inflammatory cytokine response, but with minimal pathology. The study suggests that RVFV pathogenesis in mice is associated with liver dysfunction due to necrosis and hepatitis, while the long-term course of the disease is neurologic in nature. These findings are supported by observations of human disease and the BALB/c mouse model. The study highlights the importance of understanding the host response to RVFV infection to develop effective vaccines and treatments.
Researchers investigated the role of C-C motif chemokine ligand 20 (CCL20) in chemoresistance in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) patients undergoing taxane-containing chemotherapy. They found that CCL20 levels were significantly elevated in patients who did not achieve a complete response to chemotherapy. The study revealed that CCL20 promotes the self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) through the activation of the p65 nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) pathway, mediated by protein kinase Cζ (PKCζ) or p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK). This activation increases the frequency and taxane resistance of BCSCs. Additionally, CCL20 promotes the expression of ATP-binding cassette subfamily B member 1 (ABCB1), leading to the extracellular efflux of taxane, further contributing to chemoresistance. A positive feedback loop between NF-κB and CCL20 pathways was identified, sustaining chemoresistance in breast cancer cells. The study suggests that CCL20 can be a novel predictive marker for taxane response, and blocking CCL20 or its downstream pathway may reverse taxane resistance in breast cancer patients. The findings propose a novel strategy to overcome taxane resistance in TNBC by combining taxane treatment with the adjuvant pharmacological inhibition of ABCB1.
Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that can infect virtually all nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals. The parasite's ability to infect and manipulate its host is dependent on its ability to transport "GRA" proteins across the parasitophorous vacuole membrane (PVM) into the host cell. GRA proteins have diverse roles in Toxoplasma's intracellular lifecycle, including co-opting host cell functions and proteins. However, the translocation process and its machinery are not well understood. A previous study identified a novel protein, TgMYR1, which is essential for GRA transport into the host cell. To identify additional proteins necessary for effector transport, researchers screened Toxoplasma mutants defective in c-Myc up-regulation for their ability to export GRA16 and GRA24 to the host cell nucleus. The study found that novel proteins MYR2 and MYR3 play a crucial role in translocation of a subset of GRAs into the host cell. MYR2 and MYR3 are secreted into the PV space and co-localize with PV membranes and MYR1. The researchers also showed that fusing intrinsically disordered effectors to a structured DHFR domain blocks the transport of other effectors, consistent with a translocon-based model of effector transport. Overall, these results reveal a novel complex at the PVM that is essential for effector translocation into the host cell.
Researchers investigated the role of the origin recognition complex 2 (ORC2) in the replication of papillomaviruses, specifically human papillomavirus (HPV) and bovine papillomavirus type-1 (BPV-1). They found that the E2 protein of these viruses binds to ORC2, but surprisingly, ORC2 is not present at the viral origin of replication. Depletion of ORC2 actually increased viral replication in certain cell lines, suggesting that ORC2 suppresses the replicative function of E2. Furthermore, over-expression of HPV E2 decreased ORC2 occupation at mammalian origins of replication, indicating that E2 restricts pre-ORC assembly, which could otherwise compete for host replication complexes necessary for viral genome amplification. The researchers propose that the ORC2 complex with E2 restricts viral replication in the maintenance phase of the viral replication program, and that elevated levels of E2 during the differentiation-dependent amplification stage subvert ORC loading and DNA synthesis at cellular origins. These findings provide new insights into the complex interplay between viral and host replication factors during papillomavirus replication.
A study was conducted to investigate the presence of Brucella DNA in bovine milk in the urban and peri-urban area of Dushanbe, Tajikistan. A total of 564 cow milk samples were collected from 326 herds in 21 villages, and Brucella DNA was detected in 10.3% of the samples using IS711-based real-time PCR. The presence of Brucella DNA was found in both seropositive and seronegative cows, with 100% of seropositive cows and 8.3% of seronegative cows testing positive. Sequence analysis of the rpoB gene suggested that one cow was infected with B. abortus and another cow was likely infected with B. melitensis. The study highlights the need for implementing complementary diagnostic strategies to detect false serological negative individuals in Brucella surveillance, control, and eradication programs. The results also suggest that vaccination of cattle with S19 and small ruminants with Rev 1 may be necessary to control Brucella infections in the livestock population. However, further research is required to obtain a comprehensive understanding of the Brucella spp. circulating among the livestock in the region. The study's findings are concerning, given the common consumption of unpasteurized dairy products in the region.
Researchers studied the role of histone H3 lysine 27 methylation (H3K27me3) in maintaining chromosome stability in the pathogenic fungus Zymoseptoria tritici. This fungus has eight accessory chromosomes that are highly unstable during cell division and transcriptionally repressed. The researchers deleted the genes responsible for H3K27me3 and H3K9me3, a related histone modification, and analyzed the impact on chromosome and genome stability. They found that the absence of H3K9me3 led to dramatic chromatin reorganization, with H3K27me3 being relocalized to regions enriched with H3K9me3 in wild-type strains. This resulted in many genome rearrangements and the formation of new chromosomes, accompanied by the activation of transposable elements. In contrast, the loss of H3K27me3 increased the stability of accessory chromosomes under normal growth conditions, without significant changes in gene activity. The study suggests that H3K9me3 is crucial for maintaining genome stability by preventing H3K27me3 in regions considered constitutive heterochromatin. The findings provide insights into the role of heterochromatin in genome stability and suggest that H3K27me3 reduces the overall stability of accessory chromosomes, creating a "metastable" state for these quasi-essential regions of the genome. The study provides a basis for future research on the influence of heterochromatin on structural genome rearrangements using Z. tritici as a model organism.
Researchers evaluated the cost-effectiveness of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) vaccination strategies for rabies in low-income countries. They found that PEP vaccination is an extremely cost-effective intervention, with costs ranging from $200 to less than $60 per death averted. The study compared intramuscular (IM) and intradermal (ID) administration of PEP and found that switching to ID regimens resulted in significant cost savings due to reduced vaccine volume requirements. This could mitigate vaccine shortages and reduce costs for healthcare providers.

The researchers also explored financing mechanisms to make PEP more accessible and affordable for those in need. They suggest that a universal switch to ID delivery could improve affordability and accessibility of PEP, leading to a likely reduction in human rabies deaths. The study demonstrates that ID delivery of PEP is considerably more cost-effective than IM delivery in terms of averting rabies cases and saving lives.

The study highlights the importance of increasing accessibility, reducing costs, and preventing delays in delivering PEP, particularly in low-income countries where the burden of rabies falls heavily on the poorest sectors of society. The researchers propose concurrent changes in PEP costs to patients, which could improve affordability and provide incentives for compliance without compromising existing health budgets.
Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite, has developed a mechanism to acquire nutrients by attracting host organelles to the parasitophorous vacuole (PV) where it replicates. Research has shown that Toxoplasma exploits host lipid droplets (LD), a type of fat storage organelle, as a source of lipids. The study found that Toxoplasma replication is reduced in host cells depleted of LD or impaired in lipolysis or fatty acid catabolism. In infected cells, the number of host LD and expression of LD-associated genes increase, and the PV is surrounded by host LD. Toxoplasma can access lipids stored in host LD and incorporate them into its own membranes and LD. The parasite can also intercept and internalize host LD within the PV, some of which remain associated with Rab7 and become wrapped by an intravacuolar network of membranes (IVN). Mutant parasites impaired in IVN formation have a diminished capacity for lipid uptake from host LD. Additionally, parasites lacking an IVN-localized phospholipase A2 are less proficient in salvaging lipids from host LD. The study highlights Toxoplasma's reliance on host LD for its intracellular development and its ability to scavenge neutral lipids from host LD.
Researchers have identified chalcones, a type of flavonoid derivative, as potential inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica cathepsin L enzymes. Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke parasite that causes fasciolosis, a disease affecting cattle and sheep, and can also infect humans. The parasite's cathepsin L enzymes play a crucial role in its development and survival. Triclabendazole is currently the primary treatment for fasciolosis, but resistance to this drug has been reported in several countries, highlighting the need for new treatment options.

A library of 40 flavonoid derivatives was screened for inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica cysteine proteases, and chalcones with phenyl and naphthyl groups were found to be effective inhibitors. One compound, C34, was identified as a potent inhibitor of the juvenile-specific cathepsin L enzyme FhCL3, with an IC50 of 5.6 μM. C34 was shown to bind to the enzyme's active site and inhibit its activity, leading to a reduction in the parasite's ability to migrate through the gut wall and a loss of motility, ultimately resulting in the parasite's death.

This study is the first to report the in vitro screening of non-peptidic inhibitors of Fasciola cathepsin L enzymes. The findings suggest that chalcones may be a promising new class of compounds for the treatment of fasciolosis and potentially other helminthic diseases. Further research is needed to develop these compounds into effective treatments.
Researchers investigated how the visual system transmits information about changes in light intensity through separate neural pathways. They used in vivo imaging to study how bipolar cells (BCs) transmit signals to the inner retina. The study found that the volume of the synaptic terminal is an intrinsic property that contributes to different temporal filters. Individual cells have multiple terminals of varying sizes, with smaller terminals generating faster and larger calcium transients to trigger vesicle release with higher initial gain, followed by more profound adaptation. Smaller terminals transmitted higher stimulus frequencies more effectively.

Measurements of presynaptic calcium signals in BCs showed a strongly rectifying function of light intensity, causing a steady increase in calcium that was graded with contrast. Voltage-dependent calcium channels in the synaptic terminal of BCs were found to be responsible for the first major non-linear transformation of the visual signal as it is transmitted through the retina.

The study also found that variations in filtering of the presynaptic calcium signal impact the output from the synapse. Smaller terminals responded to a step of light with higher relative release rates, but the resolution was too low to detect modulations at stimulus frequencies above 1 Hz. The synaptic output of BCs was found to be strongly rectified, with an increase in stimulus variance causing an increase in the mean rate of vesicle release even when the mean luminance was held constant.

A model was used to quantify time-dependent changes in synaptic gain, predicting that the rate of vesicle release would depress more profoundly in smaller terminals. Whole-cell recordings from the large terminal of "mixed" BCs were made to compare presynaptic calcium signals in the large and small compartments. The results indicate how one neuron can transmit different temporal components in the visual signal through synaptic terminals of varying geometries with different adaptational properties.
Researchers have developed a new method for detecting and analyzing individual synapses in the brain using multiplex fluorescence microscopy (muxFM) image data. The method, called a probabilistic synapse detector, uses machine learning algorithms to identify synapses based on their molecular and morphological characteristics. This approach combines the advantages of fluorescence microscopy, which offers high speed and low cost, with the precision of electron microscopy (EM), which is considered the gold standard for synapse detection.

The new method was tested using datasets from conjugate array tomography (cAT), which provides both fluorescence and EM images of the same individual synapses. The results showed that the probabilistic synapse detector was able to detect synapses from muxFM data as accurately as human annotators, and accurately reproduced known features of cortical synapse distributions. This method has the potential to enable large-scale synapse detection and analysis, allowing researchers to study the relationships between detected synapses and their parent neurons.

The probabilistic synapse detector may also be useful for analyzing standard confocal and super-resolution FM images, where EM cross-validation is not practical. This new approach opens the door to data-driven discovery of new synapse types and their density, and has the potential to revolutionize our understanding of the brain's synaptic networks.
Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a crucial role in various cellular processes, including nucleic acid metabolism, gene expression, and immune system function. Impairment of zinc homeostasis can lead to various human pathologies. Mammalian zinc transport is mediated by two families of transporters, ZnT and ZIP, with ZnT2 being responsible for vesicular zinc accumulation and secretion into breast milk during lactation. However, the mechanism of action of ZnT2 is not well understood, particularly the coupling of zinc transport to the proton gradient in acidic vesicles.

Researchers have modeled the mechanism of action of ZnT2 and demonstrated that it is a proton-coupled zinc antiporter. Using functional zinc transport assays, they showed that ZnT2-dependent zinc transport into intracellular vesicles is abolished by bafilomycin A1, a specific inhibitor of vacuolar-type proton ATPase. Additionally, they used LysoTracker Red and Lyso-pHluorin to show that ZnT2 overexpression in intracellular vesicles leads to alkalization of the vesicular pH upon addition of exogenous zinc, which is reversed by TPEN, a specific zinc chelator. Computational energy calculations suggest that ZnT2 functions as an antiporter with a stoichiometry of 2H+/Zn2+ ions. This indicates that ZnT2 is a proton motive force-driven, electroneutral vesicular zinc exchanger that concentrates zinc in acidic vesicles at the expense of proton extrusion to the cytoplasm.
Researchers have discovered that 14-3-3 proteins play a crucial role in regulating the processing of stalled replication forks, which is essential for maintaining genome stability. Replication fork integrity is monitored by checkpoint-mediated phosphorylation events, and 14-3-3 proteins bind to phosphorylated proteins. The study found that 14-3-3 proteins interact with Exonuclease 1 (Exo1), an enzyme that processes stalled replication forks in yeast and mammalian cells. In yeast cells lacking 14-3-3 proteins, Exo1-dependent single-stranded DNA gaps accumulate at stalled forks, leading to persistent checkpoint activation and recovery defects. This suggests that 14-3-3 proteins help control the phosphorylation status of Exo1 and other unknown targets, promoting fork progression, stability, and restart in response to DNA replication stress. The study also shows that 14-3-3 proteins facilitate fork progression under limiting nucleotide concentrations. The findings propose that 14-3-3 proteins act as central integrators of signals that regulate fork stability and processing. The research highlights the importance of 14-3-3 proteins in maintaining genome stability and suggests that they may regulate additional targets during replication stress, possibly through modulation of their phosphorylation.
Researchers investigated the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) in human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) infection and pathogenesis using a humanized mouse model. They developed a monoclonal antibody that specifically depletes human pDC in lymphoid organs, allowing them to study the effects of pDC depletion on HIV-1 infection. The results showed that pDC play a dual role in HIV-1 infection: they suppress HIV-1 replication by producing type I interferons (IFN-I), but also contribute to HIV-1-induced immunopathogenesis by promoting cell death of human leukocytes, including CD4 and CD8 T cells. During acute HIV-1 infection, pDC depletion abolished the induction of IFN-I and interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs), leading to increased HIV-1 replication. In contrast, during chronic HIV-1 infection, pDC depletion reduced the induction of IFN-I and ISGs, associated with elevated HIV-1 replication and reduced cell death of human leukocytes. The study suggests that pDC depletion and IFN-I blockade may provide novel strategies for treating HIV-1 immune non-responsive patients with persistent immune activation despite effective antiretrovirus treatment. The findings highlight the complex role of pDC in HIV-1 infection and pathogenesis, and provide new insights into the mechanisms underlying HIV-1-induced immunopathogenesis.
Sulforaphane (SFN), a compound found in cruciferous vegetables, has been shown to inhibit HIV infection in primary macrophages through the activation of the transcription regulator Nrf2. Nrf2 is a protein that regulates the expression of anti-oxidant genes, and its activation has been linked to the inhibition of various viruses, including Marburg virus, Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus, and Dengue virus. However, the impact of Nrf2 activation on HIV infection had not been previously tested.

In this study, researchers found that SFN blocks HIV infection in primary macrophages, but not in primary T cells or other cell lines. The anti-viral effects of SFN were found to be mediated through Nrf2, as siRNA-mediated depletion of Nrf2 boosted HIV infectivity in primary macrophages and reduced the anti-viral effects of SFN treatment. The researchers also found that SFN treatment blocks HIV infection after entry, but before the formation of 2-LTR circles, similar to the type I interferon-induced cellular anti-viral proteins SAMHD1 and MX2.

The study suggests that Nrf2 action can potently block HIV infection and highlights a novel way to trigger this inhibition. The researchers also found that the basal level of Nrf2 present in macrophages is sufficient to establish some anti-viral activity, and that SFN triggers a block to HIV infection in myeloid-derived cells, including primary macrophages, but not in primary T cells.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in rural western Kenya to investigate the prevalence and risk factors of geohelminth infections among pregnant women. The study found that 76.2% of the 390 participants who provided a stool sample were infected with at least one geohelminth species, with Ascaris lumbricoides being the most prevalent (52.3%), followed by hookworm (39.5%) and Trichuris trichiura (29.0%). Geohelminth infections were associated with the use of an unprotected water source and the lack of treatment of drinking water, but not with clinical symptoms or low body mass index.

The study also found that hookworm infection was associated with a lower mid-upper arm circumference, and that hookworm infections with an egg count of 1000 or more per gram of feces were associated with lower hemoglobin levels. In contrast, Ascaris lumbricoides infection was associated with a lower risk of malaria parasitemia among women in their second or third trimester of pregnancy. The study suggests that routine provision of antihelminth treatment during antenatal clinic visits may be beneficial, but further evaluation of the impact on pregnancy, malaria, and birth outcomes is needed.
Mycolactone, a compound produced by the skin pathogen Mycobacterium ulcerans, has been found to have anti-inflammatory effects on the nervous system. Research has shown that mycolactone blocks the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by immune cells, leading to immunomodulatory properties. This study investigated whether mycolactone affects the inflammatory responses of sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia, which are involved in pain perception, transmission, and maintenance. The study found that mycolactone suppressed the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by these cells without affecting their viability. In fact, nanomolar concentrations of mycolactone efficiently suppressed the production of pro-inflammatory mediators within the first 24 hours of treatment. The study also found that mycolactone prevented the pro-inflammatory polarization of cortical microglia, which play a critical role in neuroinflammation. In a rat model of neuropathic pain, mycolactone was injected into the spinal canal to test its effects on neuroinflammation. The results showed that mycolactone decreased the local production of inflammatory cytokines without inducing detectable cytotoxicity. This study provides evidence that mycolactone suppresses the inflammatory responses of sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia, which may contribute to its analgesic properties. The findings suggest that mycolactone may be a potential therapeutic agent for treating chronic pain, particularly neuropathic pain.
Researchers investigated the relationship between genetic variations and the outcome of human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) in Guinea. HAT, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, has varying clinical outcomes in its human host, ranging from rapid progression to a self-curing state. The study aimed to determine if host genetic factors contribute to this diversity. A total of 425 individuals, including 232 HAT cases, 79 individuals with long-lasting positive serology but negative parasitology, and 114 endemic controls, were included in the study. Genotypes of 28 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in eight genes were analyzed for association with HAT outcome. The results showed that the IL6 rs1818879 allele A was associated with a lower risk of progressing from latent infection to active disease. In contrast, the MIF rs36086171 allele G and MIF rs12483859 C allele were associated with an increased risk of latent infections. The APOL1 G2 allele (DEL) was found to be associated with a higher risk of developing HAT, while the APOL1 G1 polymorphism was associated with a lower risk. No associations were found with other candidate genes. These findings suggest that host genes, particularly IL6 rs1818879, play a role in modulating Trypanosoma brucei gambiense infection outcome in infected individuals from Guinea. This study contributes to the understanding of host-parasite interactions and may lead to the development of new control tools for HAT.
Researchers conducted deep whole-genome sequencing on 38 individuals from the general population of Singapore, who are primarily descendants of immigrants from Dravidian-language-speaking states in south India.
