RSM1 expression was dynamically regulated by ABA and NaCl, and genetic analyses revealed that RSM1 mediated multiple functions of HY5 in responses to ABA and abiotic stresses. Pull-down and BiFC assays confirmed the interaction between RSM1 and HY5/HYH in vitro and in vivo. The study suggests that RSM1 and HY5/HYH may function as a regulatory module in responses to ABA and abiotic stresses. Furthermore, RSM1 was found to bind to the promoter of ABA INSENSITIVE 5 (ABI5), thereby regulating its expression, and stimulate HY5 binding to the ABI5 promoter. The results indicate that HY5/HYH and RSM1 may converge on the ABI5 promoter and independently or dependently regulate ABI5 expression and ABI5-downstream ABA and abiotic stress-responsive genes, thereby improving plant adaptation to the environment.
Mitochondrial complex I, the largest and most complex proton pump in the respiratory chain, plays a crucial role in cellular energy metabolism by linking electron transfer from NADH to ubiquinone to the pumping of four protons from the matrix into the intermembrane space. Defects in complex I have been implicated in various degenerative disorders, including neurodegenerative diseases and biological aging. Recent X-ray structural analysis of prokaryotic and eukaryotic complex I revealed that the redox reactions occur in the hydrophilic peripheral arm of the L-shaped molecule, far from the membrane domain. This suggests that the proton pumping within the membrane arm of complex I is driven indirectly through long-range conformational coupling. However, the molecular mechanism and the number, identity, and localization of the pump-sites remain unclear.

To investigate this, researchers deleted the gene for a small accessory subunit of the Yarrowia complex I, resulting in a stable subcomplex (nb8mΔ) that lacks the distal part of the membrane domain. Analysis of the subunit composition of the holo and subcomplex revealed that two subunits (ND4 and ND5) with homology to bacterial Mrp-type Na+/H+ antiporters were missing in nb8mΔ. Despite this, nb8mΔ still pumped protons at half the stoichiometry of the complete enzyme. These findings suggest that the membrane arm of complex I harbors two functionally distinct pump modules connected in series by a long helical transmission element.
Researchers investigated the effect of febrile temperatures on the binding affinity of antibodies to malarial and dengue antigens. They used Isothermal Titration Calorimetry (ITC) and Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) to measure the binding affinity of specific monoclonal antibodies to these antigens at different temperatures: 37°C (physiological temperature), 40°C (febrile temperature), and 42°C (pathophysiological temperature). The results showed that the binding affinity of the antibodies to the antigens increased significantly at 40°C compared to 37°C or 42°C. This increase in affinity was observed for both malarial and dengue antigens. The researchers also found that thermal equilibration of the protein partners prior to measurement further increased their binding affinity. This suggests that fever may play a positive role in modulating the immune response to infection by enhancing the binding affinity of antibodies to antigens. The study highlights the potential benefits of thermal priming in enhancing protein-protein affinity, particularly for samples with limited availability. The findings have implications for the development of diagnostic and therapeutic strategies for infectious diseases caused by malarial and dengue viruses.
Researchers have investigated how actomyosin-based cortical flow, a fundamental process in cellular morphogenesis, is controlled by local remodeling of cross-linked networks of actin filaments and myosin motors. They developed a computational model that incorporates minimal requirements for contractile stress production and dissipation, including asymmetric filament compliance, spatial heterogeneity of motor activity, reversible cross-links, and filament turnover. The model predicts that filament turnover is necessary to maintain active stress against external resistance and steady-state flow in response to external stress. Steady-state stress increases with filament lifetime up to a characteristic time τm, then decreases with lifetime above τm. Effective viscosity increases with filament lifetime up to a characteristic time τc, and then becomes independent of filament lifetime and sharply dependent on cross-link dynamics. These dependencies define multiple regimes of steady-state flow. When filament lifetimes are shorter than both τc and τm, the dependencies of effective viscosity and steady-state stress on filament turnover cancel each other, resulting in flow speed being insensitive to filament turnover and showing a simple dependence on motor activity and cross-link dynamics. The study provides a framework for understanding how animal cells control cortical flow through local control of network remodeling. The findings suggest that local interactions among actin filaments and myosin motors are sufficient to drive macroscopic contraction of disordered networks in vitro, supporting a mechanism based on asymmetrical filament compliance and filament buckling.
Researchers have identified a genetic locus, GSQ11, in Arabidopsis thaliana that confers sugar insensitivity in seedlings. A quantitative trait locus (QTL) analysis was performed on a Col/C24 F2 population, and GSQ11 was mapped to the ANAC060 gene. Allelism tests and transgenic complementation confirmed that GSQ11 lies within ANAC060. The Col ANAC060 allele was found to be dominant over the sugar-sensitive C24 allele and conferred sugar insensitivity. Genomic and mRNA analyses revealed a single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in Col ANAC060 that affects splicing patterns, resulting in a truncated protein lacking the transmembrane domain (TMD) present in the C24 ANAC060 protein. This truncated protein is localized to the nucleus and is found in approximately 12% of natural Arabidopsis accessions. The expression of GSQ11/ANAC060 is induced by glucose in a process that requires abscisic acid (ABA) signaling. Chromatin immunoprecipitation-qPCR and transient expression analysis showed that ABI4 directly binds to the GSQ11/ANAC060 promoter to activate transcription. Interestingly, Col ANAC060 reduced ABA sensitivity and Glc-induced ABA accumulation, and ABI4 expression was also reduced in Col ANAC060 lines. This suggests that the sugar-ABA signaling cascade induces ANAC060 expression, but the truncated Col ANAC060 protein attenuates ABA induction and ABA signaling, resulting in sugar insensitivity.
Researchers have investigated the molecular mechanisms underlying cyclic di-GMP (c-di-GMP) signaling in Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a bacterium that can form biofilms and exhibit various motility behaviors. c-di-GMP is a second messenger molecule that regulates numerous cellular functions, including the transition from planktonic cells to biofilm communities. To understand how c-di-GMP signaling achieves specificity, the study focused on the HptB regulatory cascade, which controls biofilm formation, motility, and chemotaxis in P. aeruginosa. The researchers discovered that the diguanylate cyclase HsbD interacts with the HptB pathway to regulate these behaviors. HsbD is a c-di-GMP synthase that produces c-di-GMP, which in turn affects the activity of the HptB pathway. The study found that HsbD and another c-di-GMP synthase, SadC, have distinct roles in the HptB-dependent regulation of biofilm formation and motility. While SadC is involved in biofilm formation and hyper-swarming, HsbD affects swimming and twitching motility. The researchers propose that HsbD acts locally at the cell pole and that the two c-di-GMP synthases intersect within the same global regulatory network, the Gac/Rsm cascade, in a hierarchical order. This study provides an example of how c-di-GMP signaling gains output specificity in P. aeruginosa and sheds light on the evolution of c-di-GMP signaling in bacteria. The findings suggest that the rewiring of c-di-GMP signaling into the HptB cascade relies on the interaction between HsbD and HsbA, an anti-anti-sigma factor, and the control of HsbD's dynamic localization at the cell poles.
Researchers investigated how humans learn and generalize visuomotor mappings, which are associations between visual cues and motor responses. Participants performed a rapid target-pointing task while visual feedback was manipulated to require different visuomotor mappings depending on the target shape. The target shapes were morphed between spiky and circular shapes, and participants learned to associate each shape with a specific visuomotor mapping. After training, participants were tested on novel target shapes that had not been learned previously.

The results showed that participants applied the mapping corresponding to the trained shape that was most similar to the current one, consistent with a Bayesian learning model. This model predicts that learning should slow down with increased numbers of training pairs, which was confirmed by the results. The study found a good correspondence between the Bayesian learning model and the empirical results, suggesting that this model may be a possible mechanism for learning multiple visuomotor mappings.

The study also investigated whether participants could explicitly extract the linear relationship between target shape and visuomotor mapping and generalize accordingly. However, the results showed that learning the associations required explicit awareness of the cues' role, and participants applied the mapping corresponding to the trained shape that was most similar to the current one. This suggests that the learning process is more complex than a simple linear relationship between shape and mapping. The study's findings have implications for our understanding of how humans learn and generalize visuomotor mappings, and may have applications in fields such as robotics and rehabilitation.
Researchers investigated the relationship between climbing fiber bursts and olivary sub-threshold oscillations in the inferior olivary nucleus, a key input to the cerebellum. Climbing fibers transmit information from the inferior olivary nucleus to the cerebellum and are thought to play a role in timing motor commands and motor learning. Previous studies suggested that the size of the climbing fiber burst is related to the phase of the olivary cell's sub-threshold membrane potential oscillation. A three-compartmental model of an inferior olivary cell was used to explore the factors determining the size of the climbing fiber burst. The results showed that the phase-dependency of the burst size is present but limited, and that charge flow between the soma and dendrite is a major determinant of the climbing fiber burst. The study also found that phenomena such as cell ensemble synchrony can affect the climbing fiber burst size through dendrodendritic gap-junctional coupling between olivary cells. The findings suggest that the inferior olivary nucleus may be able to transmit more information per event than previously thought, potentially allowing for a coarse, low-resolution encoding of temporal information. The study's results have implications for understanding the electrophysiological properties of the inferior olivary nucleus and its role in the cerebellar system.
Researchers have developed a computational model of liver iron metabolism to better understand how the liver regulates iron levels in the body. Iron is essential for life, but excessive levels can be toxic, leading to various diseases. The liver plays a crucial role in maintaining safe iron levels through a complex biochemical network involving iron absorption, transport, storage, and regulation. A peptide hormone called hepcidin is secreted by the liver to regulate systemic iron metabolism.

The model was constructed based on known mechanisms of regulation and kinetic properties obtained from several publications. It was validated by comparing its results with previously published physiological data and was able to reproduce multiple experimental findings. The model was used to simulate a time course of iron metabolism following an oral dose of iron, which recreated the dynamics and time scale of the system's response to iron challenge. Additionally, a disease state simulation of haemochromatosis was created by altering a single reaction parameter that mimics a human haemochromatosis gene mutation, providing a quantitative understanding of the liver iron overload that arises in this disease.

This model provides a comprehensive description of liver iron regulation and can be used to elucidate the link from genotype to phenotype, as demonstrated with hereditary haemochromatosis. The model's predictions about liver iron regulation should be investigated further, and it can be used to identify valuable drug targets and design experiments to improve our understanding of this system. This computational model constitutes a clinical translational approach, integrating data from multiple sources to improve our understanding of human iron metabolism.
Researchers have developed a computational model to simulate the process of nucleocytoplasmic transport (NCT) through the nuclear pore complex (NPC). The NPC is a critical structure that regulates the movement of molecules between the nucleus and cytoplasm in eukaryotic cells. The model takes into account the hydrophobic interactions between karyopherins (kaps) and Phe-Gly (FG) repeat domains, which play a key role in the transport process. The researchers used Brownian dynamics simulations to study the movement of cargo complexes through the NPC.

The model predicts that the first-passage time for a 15-nanometer cargo complex is approximately 2.6 milliseconds, with an inverse Gaussian distribution. The simulations also show that the cargo complex is primarily attached to the channel wall and interacts with the FG-layer as it passes through the central channel. The model suggests that the kap-FG hydrophobic interaction is highly dynamic and fast, allowing for efficient translocation through the NPC. Additionally, the researchers found that almost all eight hydrophobic binding spots on kap-β are occupied simultaneously during transport.

The study also investigated the role of cytoplasmic filaments in the selectivity barrier of the NPC. The results show that cytoplasmic filaments-deficient NPCs have a high degree of permeability to inert cargos, indicating that these filaments play a crucial role in the selectivity barrier. The model provides new insights into the molecular events that occur during NCT and can be used as a foundation for future studies on this complex process.
Determining the optimal infectious dose of a pathogen for nonhuman primate (NHP) models is crucial for testing interventions against human pathogens such as HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria. A limiting dose challenge model, where only a fraction of animals become infected, is often used to minimize animal use while achieving statistically significant and biologically meaningful results. However, this approach requires careful titration of the infectious agent to avoid false negative or false positive results.

To address this challenge, a new protocol has been developed to determine the dose of pathogen that infects 50% of the time, known as the AID50. This protocol minimizes the number of animals and resources required while providing an estimate of the AID50 within 1.5-fold of the true value. The method involves iterative exposures of cohorts of animals to a dilution of the pathogen stock, adjusting the dose between each round to achieve 50% infection.

The protocol is generalizable to any pathogen and animal model, but is most critical for NHP models where ethical considerations mandate minimization of animal use. On average, the protocol requires 15 animals, 3 phase 1 rounds, and results in an estimate of the AID50 within 40% of the true value. By following this protocol, investigators can efficiently determine the optimal infectious dose of a pathogen for NHP models, reducing the need for excessive animal use and resources.
Researchers studied the auditory neuron AN2 in crickets to understand how sensory systems adapt to changes in their environment. They found that the AN2 neuron adapts to amplitude-modulated sound stimuli by shifting its response curve towards higher stimulus intensities, with a time constant of 1.5 seconds for adaptation and recovery. This means that the neuron reduces its response to low-intensity sounds.

The researchers tested whether this adaptation improves the representation of the signal by comparing it to two competing hypotheses: infomax and selective coding. Infomax predicts that the neuron should maximize the information conveyed about the entire signal range, while selective coding suggests that the neuron should enhance "foreground" signals and suppress "background" signals.

To test these hypotheses, the researchers presented the AN2 neuron with signals with two or three peaks in their amplitude distributions, mimicking auditory scenes with multiple signals. They found that adaptation reduces the amount of encoded information when considering the whole range of input signals, contradicting the infomax principle. Additionally, the response curve changes were not consistent with the selective coding hypothesis, as the amount of information conveyed about the loudest part of the signal remained nearly constant, and less information was transmitted about signals with lower intensity.

These findings suggest that the adaptation mechanism in the AN2 neuron does not follow either of the two proposed principles, and further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms of sensory adaptation in the cricket auditory system.
Researchers have investigated the role of polybasic domains in the prion protein (PrP) in the propagation of prion diseases. Prions are infectious proteins that can cause fatal neurodegenerative disorders, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Previous studies suggested that polybasic domains on the prion protein (PrPC) interact with the disease-associated conformer (PrPSc) to facilitate prion propagation. To further explore this interaction, researchers created mutant prion proteins lacking one or both polybasic domains and expressed them in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells. These mutant proteins were used as substrates in serial protein misfolding cyclic amplification (sPMCA) reactions, which mimic the process of prion propagation.

The results showed that prions lacking the central polybasic domain (ΔC-PrPSc) were formed after several rounds of sPMCA. Surprisingly, these ΔC-PrPSc prions could bind to and induce the conversion of mutant prion proteins lacking polybasic domains into PrPSc molecules. However, ΔC-PrPSc prions displayed reduced or absent biological infectivity compared to wild-type PrPSc, despite their ability to seed sPMCA reactions in normal mouse brain homogenate. This suggests that the interaction between PrPC and PrPSc through polybasic domains may be necessary for generating prion infectivity. The findings indicate that the propagation of PrPSc molecules may not rely on a single mechanism, and that the interaction between PrPC and PrPSc through polybasic domains may be required for prion infectivity.
Researchers have developed an inverse reinforcement-learning (IRL) framework to identify animal behavioral strategies from behavioral time-series data. This framework was applied to the thermotactic behavior of Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans), a type of nematode worm, to understand how they make decisions in response to temperature changes. The study found that fed C. elegans worms use both the absolute temperature and its temporal derivative to navigate a thermal gradient, employing two strategies: directed migration (DM) and isothermal migration (IM). DM involves efficiently reaching specific temperatures, while IM involves moving along a constant temperature. In contrast, starved C. elegans worms use only the absolute temperature to avoid the cultivation temperature. The researchers also investigated the neural basis of these strategies by applying the IRL framework to thermosensory neuron-deficient worms. The results suggest that the IRL-based approach can identify animal strategies from behavioral time-series data and could be applied to a wide range of behavioral studies, including decision-making in other organisms. The study demonstrates the effectiveness of the IRL framework in understanding animal behavior and decision-making processes.
Researchers have sequenced the genome of Chrysochromulina tobin, a type of haptophyte algae, and analyzed its transcriptome over a 24-hour light/dark cycle. Haptophytes play a crucial role in aquatic ecosystems, contributing to carbon sequestration, forming harmful blooms, and serving as a food source for various aquatic organisms. Despite their importance, the nuclear genome of only one haptophyte, Emiliania huxleyi, has been previously sequenced.

The Chrysochromulina tobin genome is small, compact, and encodes approximately 16,777 genes, with a high proportion of protein-coding genes. Genes involved in fatty acid synthesis, modification, and catabolism show distinct patterns of expression over the circadian photoperiod. The genome also harbors a unique hybrid polyketide synthase/non-ribosomal peptide synthase gene complex and encodes potential anti-microbial peptides and proteins involved in multidrug and toxic compound extrusion.

The study also identified a new haptophyte xanthorhodopsin and two "red" RuBisCO activases shared across many algal lineages. The Chrysochromulina tobin genome provides new insights into the evolutionary history, ecology, and economic importance of haptophytes. The findings have implications for understanding the fundamental metabolic processes associated with harmful algal bloom events and may support commercial endeavors such as aquaculture feed stocks, nutraceuticals, plastics, or biofuel production.
Research has shown that triple-negative breast cancers, which lack the clinical markers ESR1, PGR, and HER2, often belong to the Basal-like molecular subtype and are associated with defective Rb, p53, and Brca1 pathways. Mouse genetic studies have demonstrated that the combined inactivation of Rb and p53 pathways is sufficient to suppress the physiological cell death of mammary involution. Furthermore, the concomitant inactivation of all three pathways in mammary epithelium has an additive effect on tumor latency and predisposes highly penetrant, metastatic adenocarcinomas. These tumors are poorly differentiated and exhibit histologic features common among human Brca1-mutated tumors, including heterogeneous morphology, metaplasia, and necrosis. Gene expression analyses reveal that the tumors share attributes of both Basal-like and Claudin-low signatures, two molecular subtypes encompassed by the broader, triple-negative class defined by clinical markers.

The study found that concomitant inactivation of all three tumor suppressor pathways in mammary epithelium has an additive effect on tumor latency and predisposes highly penetrant, malignant carcinomas. Brca1 inactivation accelerated tumorigenesis compared to TP tumors, but no statistical difference was observed between chromosomal copy number transitions in tumors with or without Brca1. Mouse models that mimic the complexity of triple-negative breast cancer will be invaluable tools for defining the diverse cellular biology and behavior of these tumors and for rigorously triaging new drug candidates. The study demonstrates that mammary tumors caused by inactivation of the pRb family of proteins, together with Brca1 and p53 inactivation, mimic several aspects of the most aggressive forms of breast cancer, including rapid tumor progression, poor differentiation, distant metastasis, necrosis, metaplasia, and genomic instability.
Aedes aegypti (L.) is the primary vector of dengue, a major arboviral infection worldwide. To prevent and control dengue transmission, accurate predictions of vector populations are essential. Aedes aegypti primarily develops in artificial water-holding containers, and most adult mosquitoes do not disperse over long distances. Containers in areas with high development site density are more likely to be used as oviposition sites and produce adult mosquitoes at a higher rate.

A study conducted in rural Kamphaeng Phet, Thailand, from 2004 to 2007, collected 84,840 samples of water-holding containers to estimate model parameters. Regression modeling was used to assess the effect of larval development site density, access to piped water, and seasonal variation on container productivity. The results showed that the number of suitable larval development sites and their density in the environment were the primary determinants of the distribution and abundance of Aedes aegypti pupae.

The study found that the productivity of most container types increased significantly as habitat density increased. An ecological approach, accounting for development site density, is essential for predicting Aedes aegypti population levels and developing efficient vector control programs. The study's findings suggest that incorporating development site density into vector control efforts, along with research on the ecology within larval development sites, will lead to a more cohesive understanding of Aedes aegypti population dynamics and contribute to the design of increasingly effective vector interventions.
In the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, the conserved Target of Rapamycin complex 2 (TORC2) plays a crucial role in regulating phenotypic plasticity in response to environmental cues and feeding state. Research has shown that TORC2 acts in the intestine to modulate neuronal expression of the daf-7 TGF-β and daf-28 insulin-like peptide genes, which reflect bacterial-diet dependent feeding status. This integration of food signals with external cues is essential for the regulation of neuroendocrine gene expression and the execution of appropriate behavioral and developmental decisions.

During larval development, pheromone, bacterial food, and temperature regulate the expression of daf-7 and daf-28 in sensory neurons, promoting a binary decision between reproductive growth and entry into the alternate dauer larval stage. In the adult, TORC2 also acts in the intestine to modulate food-regulated foraging behaviors via a PDF-2/PDFR-1 neuropeptide signaling-dependent pathway.

Genetic variation affects food-dependent larval and adult phenotypes, and quantitative trait loci (QTL) associated with these traits have been identified. These findings suggest that TORC2 acts as a hub for communication of feeding state information from the gut to the brain, contributing to the modulation of neuronal function by internal state. The research highlights the importance of TORC2 in regulating phenotypic plasticity in response to environmental cues and feeding state in C. elegans.
Researchers have identified clusters of genes that are upregulated in pluripotent cells, including embryonic stem (ES) cells and primordial germ cells. These genes are involved in various biological processes such as transcription, chromatin remodeling, cell cycle, and DNA repair. A novel computational algorithm, CompMoby, was developed to systematically predict short DNA motifs that regulate gene expression. CompMoby combines analyses of aligned and non-aligned sequences between different genomes with a probabilistic segmentation model. The algorithm was used to identify conserved overrepresented motifs in genes upregulated in pluripotent cells. These motifs were found to be preferentially active in undifferentiated mouse ES and embryonic germ cells in a sequence-specific manner and can act as enhancers in the context of an endogenous promoter. Importantly, the activity of these motifs is conserved in human ES cells. The transcription factor NF-Y was identified as a regulator of gene expression in ES cells that is required for their proliferation. NF-Y specifically binds to one of the motifs and is differentially expressed during ES cell differentiation. This study provides novel insights into the transcriptional regulatory networks of pluripotent cells and suggests that this systematic approach can be broadly applied to understanding transcriptional networks in mammalian species. The findings have implications for understanding the transcriptional regulatory networks that underlie early mammalian embryogenesis and ES cell self-renewal and pluripotency.
Researchers have characterized the structure of a complex between the nucleoprotein (N) and phosphoprotein (P) of the vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV), a non-segmented negative-strand RNA virus. The complex, consisting of a variant of N lacking its 21 N-terminal residues (NΔ21) and a 60-amino acid peptide of P (P60), was crystallized in a decameric circular form and solved at 3.0 Å resolution. The structure reveals how the molecular recognition element (MoRE) of P binds to N and competes with RNA binding and N polymerization.

Small-angle X-ray scattering and NMR spectroscopy experiments confirmed the binding of the MoRE and showed that the flanking regions of P remain flexible in the complex. The structure of the complex suggests a mechanism for the initiation of viral RNA synthesis. NMR spectroscopy also confirmed that the MoRE of P binds to N in solution as in the crystal structure, and the regions of P flanking the MoRE remain flexible in the complex.

The study demonstrates that the reconstituted NΔ21-P60 complex is a suitable model for the viral N0-P complex. The crystal structure and NMR spectroscopy experiments show that the MoRE of P, which adopts a stable conformation upon binding to N, includes residues 6 to 35 and corresponds closely to the fragment previously identified as essential and sufficient for maintaining N in a soluble form. The structure of the decameric form of the NΔ21-P60 complex reveals the molecular mechanisms by which the N0-binding MoRE of P attaches to N.
Researchers investigated the role of gap junctions in the fly visual system, specifically in the vertical system network, which plays a key role in visual processing. Gap junctions are electrical synapses that allow for direct communication between neurons. The study found that the presence of axonal gap junctions enables the vertical system to efficiently encode the axis of rotation of the fly's ego motion within 10 milliseconds of visual input onset. This encoding efficiency is near-optimal, meaning it approaches the physical limits of performance determined by the statistical structure of the visual input. The study also found that a subset of triplets of vertical system cells, connected via gap junctions, encodes motion more efficiently than the entire network and is robust to a wide range of signal-to-noise ratios. This efficient encoding is necessary for the fly's visually guided behavior, such as banked turns in evasive maneuvers. The study suggests that gap junctions only impact the system's readout, while maintaining the dendritic input intact, indicating that the computational principles implemented by neural circuitries may be more complex than previously thought. The findings provide new insights into how specific network connectivity leads to efficient encoding of sensory stimuli and may encourage exploration of gap junctions as a common mechanism for improving information transmission in other neuronal systems.
Researchers have identified human P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1 (PSGL-1) as a cellular receptor for Enterovirus 71 (EV71), a major causative agent of hand, foot, and mouth disease in children. EV71 has also been linked to various neurological diseases, including fatal cases in large outbreaks in the Asia-Pacific region. PSGL-1 is a sialomucin expressed on the surface of leukocytes that serves as a high-affinity counterreceptor for selectins and mediates leukocyte rolling on the endothelium. The interaction between PSGL-1 and P-selectin requires sulfation of at least one of three clustered tyrosines and an adjacent O-glycan expressing sialyl Lewis x in the N-terminal region of PSGL-1.

To elucidate the molecular basis of the PSGL-1-EV71 interaction, researchers generated a series of PSGL-1 mutants and identified the post-translational modifications critical for binding of PSGL-1 to EV71. They found that O-glycosylation on T57, which is critical for PSGL-1-selectin interaction, is not necessary for PSGL-1 binding to EV71. In contrast, site-directed mutagenesis at one or more potential tyrosine sulfation sites in the N-terminal region of PSGL-1 significantly impaired PSGL-1 binding to EV71. Furthermore, an inhibitor of sulfation, sodium chlorate, blocked the PSGL-1-EV71 interaction and inhibited PSGL-1-mediated viral replication of EV71 in Jurkat T cells in a dose-dependent manner. These findings suggest that tyrosine sulfation, but not O-glycosylation, in the N-terminal region of PSGL-1 is critical for EV71 infection.
Researchers investigated the therapeutic potential of mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors in treating leishmaniasis, a serious global health problem caused by Leishmania parasites. Leishmaniasis can be treated with various agents, but drug toxicity and the emergence of resistant strains limit their effectiveness. The study tested the efficacy of three mTOR inhibitors - rapamycin, GSK-2126458, and KU-0063794 - in controlling infection with Leishmania major in mice. The results showed that treatment with a clinically relevant dose of rapamycin or GSK-2126458 significantly reduced footpad swelling and parasite load in the draining lymph node, while KU-0063794 had no effect. Importantly, rapamycin did not kill the parasites in vitro. The study also found that rapamycin treatment reduced IL-4 production and increased the IFN-γ:IL-4 production ratio, indicating a T helper-type 1 (Th1)-skewed cytokine profile. Additionally, the expression level of CD69, an early activation marker, was enhanced on splenic and lymph node CD4+ and CD8+ T cells in rapamycin-treated mice. These findings suggest that select mTOR inhibitors, such as rapamycin and GSK-2126458, may be used to manage leishmaniasis by modulating the immune response. The study proposes that the adjuvanticity of mTOR inhibitors could also be exploited in vaccination strategies against Leishmania species.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between the DNA uptake sequence (DUS) and its receptor, ComP, in the process of natural transformation in Neisseria species. Natural transformation is a process by which bacteria take up free DNA, incorporate it into their genomes, and become genetically altered. To prevent the uptake of foreign DNA, some bacteria preferentially take up their own DNA, which contains specific DUS watermarks. A recent study identified ComP as the DUS receptor in Neisseria species, paving the way for a functional analysis of the DUS-ComP interdependence.

The study found that ComP is essential for transformation, both in the presence and absence of DUS. The inner bases of DUS (positions 7-10) are critical for recognition by ComP and subsequent transformation. Single base mutations in these positions led to impaired interaction with ComP and transformation. Furthermore, naturally occurring DUS variants in human Neisseria commensals, differing from DUS by only one or two bases, were found to be similarly impaired for transformation of Neisseria meningitidis.

The study also showed that a ComP homolog from a commensal species specifically binds its cognate DUS variant and mediates DUS-enhanced transformation when expressed in a comP mutant of Neisseria meningitidis. These findings suggest that a similar mechanism is used by all Neisseria species to promote transformation by their own or closely related DNA. This research sheds new light on the molecular events involved in the earliest step of natural transformation and reveals an elegant mechanism for modulating horizontal gene transfer between competent species sharing the same niche.
In fission yeast, cytokinesis requires the coordinated closure of a contractile actomyosin ring (CAR) and the synthesis of a cell wall structure called the division septum. Research has identified many CAR proteins, but how they interact with septum synthesis enzymes to form the septum remains unclear. A genetic study in fission yeast found that cooperation between the paxillin homolog Pxl1 and the enzyme Bgs1, responsible for linear β(1,3) glucan synthesis and primary septum formation, is essential for stable anchorage of the CAR to the plasma membrane before septation onset and for cleavage furrow formation. Without Pxl1 and Bgs1, the CAR fails to contract and the cell wall overgrows towards the cell lumen without septum formation. The study also found that Pxl1 concentration at the CAR increases during cytokinesis and that this increase depends on the SH3 domain of the F-BAR protein Cdc15. The absence of Pxl1 is lethal when Cdc15 function is affected, suggesting additional functions for both Pxl1 and Cdc15 proteins. The findings indicate that CAR anchorage to the plasma membrane through Cdc15 and Pxl1, and concomitant Bgs1 activity, are necessary for CAR maintenance and septum formation in fission yeast. The study suggests that Pxl1 and Bgs1 cooperate to maintain the position and integrity of the CAR during cytokinesis and are essential for the synthesis of the entire septum structure.
A recent outbreak of glanders, a highly infectious zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium Burkholderia mallei, occurred in Bahrain. To investigate the outbreak, researchers used high-resolution genotyping and comparative whole-genome sequencing to analyze B. mallei isolates from infected horses and a camel. The results suggest that the outbreak was caused by two different B. mallei strains, indicating multiple introduction events. The isolates from the Bahrain outbreak were compared to samples from a 2004 outbreak in the United Arab Emirates and placed into a broader phylogeographic context using previously published B. mallei data. The analysis revealed that the Bahrain isolates were more closely related to B. mallei from horses in the UAE in 2004 than to other B. mallei strains, suggesting repeated importation to the region from similar geographic sources. High-resolution genotyping and whole-genome analysis confirmed the same phylogenetic patterns among the samples. The close relationship between the Dubai/UAE B. mallei populations may indicate a similar geographic origin that has yet to be identified for the infecting strains. The emergence of glanders in Bahrain, combined with global horse trading, poses a new risk for human infections.
A cross-sectional observational study was conducted to investigate the clinical and parasitological features of patients with American cutaneous leishmaniasis (ACL) who did not respond to treatment with meglumine antimoniate (Glucantime). The study included 43 patients from three Colombian Army National reference centers for complicated ACL. The majority of patients (95.4%) were infected with Leishmania braziliensis, and 35% of the isolated parasites showed a significant decrease in in vitro Glucantime susceptibility after previous administration of the medication. The study found a negative correlation between lesion size and in vitro infectivity of the parasite, as well as a negative correlation between lesion size and parasite resistance to Glucantime. Leishmania braziliensis was the main parasite species associated with treatment failure or relapse. The study suggests that the indication of a second round of treatment with pentavalent antimonial derivatives in cases of therapeutic failure of ACL caused by L. braziliensis is debatable. The study's findings highlight the need for further research on the mechanisms of resistance to Glucantime and the development of new treatment strategies for ACL. The study's results also emphasize the importance of species confirmation in the diagnosis and treatment of ACL, as L. braziliensis is more prone to treatment failure than other Leishmania species.
Researchers investigated the relationship between the biosynthetic pathways of siderophores and the colibactin genotoxin in Escherichia coli. Siderophores are small iron-scavenging molecules, while colibactin is a genotoxin that contributes to the virulence of E. coli. Both pathways require a 4′-phosphopantetheinyl transferase (PPTase) for their production. Two PPTases, EntD and ClbA, have been identified, with EntD being part of the core genome and ClbA encoded on the pks pathogenicity island. The pks island is associated with the high pathogenicity island (HPI) in highly virulent E. coli strains.

The study found that ClbA can contribute to the synthesis of siderophores, including enterobactin, yersiniabactin, and salmochelins. Inactivation of both EntD and ClbA abolished the virulence of extra-intestinal pathogenic E. coli (ExPEC) in a mouse sepsis model. The presence of either functional EntD or ClbA was required for the survival of ExPEC in vivo. This suggests that ClbA is a promiscuous PPTase that can contribute to the synthesis of both the genotoxin and siderophores. The association of the pks island with HPI in highly virulent E. coli strains may have been selected because of this ability. The study highlights the complex regulatory interaction of various virulence features in E. coli and identifies potential targets for anti-virulence therapy strategies.
Researchers have developed a new probabilistic model for calculating the probability of a multiple sequence alignment given a phylogenetic tree and an evolutionary model. This model accounts for insertion and deletion events in addition to substitutions, which are not considered in widely used phylogenetic models. The new model is based on a continuous Markov process and assumes that insertion and deletion events occur one residue at a time.

The model was applied to phylogenetic tree inference by extending the program dnaml in phylip, which uses the Felsenstein peeling algorithm to efficiently calculate the probability of an ungapped multiple alignment. The extended program, dnamlε, was tested on simulated data and real ribosomal RNA alignments using standard benchmarking methods and a new "concordance test" benchmark. The results showed that dnamlε improves accuracy relative to the usual approach of ignoring gaps, while retaining the computational efficiency of the Felsenstein peeling algorithm.

The new model has the potential to integrate evolutionary modeling into probabilistic models used for other sequence analysis problems, such as hidden Markov models (HMMs) and stochastic context-free grammars (SCFGs). This could improve the accuracy of phylogenetic tree inference and other sequence analysis tasks.
Researchers investigated how the immune system responds to Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) infection in human skin. They found that Langerhans cells (LCs), a type of immune cell in the epidermis, are initially infected with HSV. These infected LCs then undergo apoptosis, or programmed cell death, and are taken up by dermal dendritic cells (DCs) in the dermis. The dermal DCs, specifically BDCA3+ and DC-SIGN+ cells, are thought to play a crucial role in presenting HSV antigens to T cells in the lymph nodes and dermis.

The study used human foreskin explants, biopsies from initial genital herpes lesions, and isolated skin cells to examine the interaction between LCs and dermal DCs. The results showed that infected LCs form clusters with dermal DCs in the dermis, and that the dermal DCs take up HSV-expressing LC fragments. This process, known as viral antigen relay, allows the immune system to recognize and respond to HSV infection.

The study suggests that targeting dermal DCs with mucosal or intradermal immunization may be an effective way to prevent HSV infection. The researchers also found that the inner foreskin model is a useful tool for studying the initial interactions between epithelia-tropic viruses and human skin. Overall, the study provides new insights into the mechanisms of HSV infection and the role of dermal DCs in the immune response.
Researchers studied the behavior of parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) in mouse macrophages infected with two species of Leishmania parasites, L. major and L. amazonensis. PVs are membrane-bound compartments that form around the parasites, allowing them to survive and replicate within the host cell. The study used multidimensional imaging to observe the formation and remodeling of PVs in live cells, providing new insights into the biology of Leishmania infection.

The researchers found that PVs formed around L. major amastigotes were typically small and tight-fitting, while those formed around L. amazonensis amastigotes were larger and more dynamic. They observed that L. major PVs underwent fission, a process where the PV splits into two smaller compartments, while L. amazonensis PVs underwent homotypic fusion, where two PVs merge to form a larger one. The study also found that the number of acidic vesicles in the host cell decreased during PV fission or enlargement, suggesting that these vesicles contribute to PV biogenesis.

The researchers used a fluorescent probe called Lysotracker to visualize acidic vesicles in the host cell and found that approximately 50 acidic vesicles were consumed during intracellular infection, contributing a hypothetical volume of 30 micrometers cubed to Leishmania PVs. This study provides new information on the dynamic behavior of Leishmania PVs and sheds light on the mechanisms of Leishmania infection, which could be useful for understanding other intracellular microorganisms.
Researchers investigated how chromatin structure influences the use of homologous sequences as donors for repair in the chicken B cell line DT40. Immunoglobulin genes in DT40 undergo regulated sequence diversification by gene conversion, a process templated by pseudogene donors. The study found that the immunoglobulin Vλ pseudogene array is characterized by histone modifications associated with active chromatin. To directly demonstrate the importance of chromatin structure for gene conversion, the researchers used a regulatable experimental system in which the heterochromatin protein HP1 was tethered to polymerized lactose operators integrated within the pseudo-Vλ donor array. Tethered HP1 diminished histone acetylation within the pseudo-Vλ array and altered the outcome of Vλ diversification, resulting in nontemplated mutations rather than templated mutations. This suggests that chromatin structure regulates homologous-directed repair. The study also found that histone modifications may contribute to maintaining genomic stability by preventing recombination between repetitive sequences. The results have practical implications for developing strategies that harness a cell's capacity for homology-dependent repair to promote gene therapy. The study's findings suggest that permissive structure at the donor will be an important design parameter in developing donor genes for therapeutic applications.
The cerebellum plays a crucial role in adjusting motor behavior to meet the demands of a given situation. Traditionally, it is believed that cerebellum-based motor learning is guided by the difference between desired and actual behavior, or error information. This error information is thought to induce lasting changes in parallel fiber synapses on Purkinje cells, which in turn mediate behavioral adjustments. However, the role of olivary climbing fibers, which connect with Purkinje cells, has been a subject of debate. Climbing fibers are believed to convey information on instant errors needed for synaptic modification, but not to contribute to error memory.

Recent studies have challenged this concept, including a previous study on short-term saccadic adaptation, which observed patterns of complex spikes (CS) that contradict the assumptions of the traditional model. In this study, researchers used a random error saccadic adaptation paradigm to investigate the role of climbing fibers in cerebellum-based motor learning. The results show that CS not only reflect the error at the time of its occurrence but also reverberate later, before a new manifestation of the behavior. This suggests that climbing fibers may play a more significant role in error memory than previously thought. The study's findings have implications for our understanding of cerebellum-based motor learning and the role of climbing fibers in this process.
Researchers have identified a potential therapeutic target for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a devastating neurodegenerative disease characterized by the loss of motor neurons and the presence of inclusions containing the protein TDP-43. Using a yeast model of ALS, the study found that overexpression of TDP-43 leads to cell shape changes and reduced ubiquitin-dependent proteolysis of a reporter construct. However, overexpression of the Hsp40 chaperone Sis1 was shown to reduce TDP-43's effects on toxicity, cell shape, and proteolysis. This protective effect was also observed in primary rodent cortical neurons when the mammalian Sis1 homologue, DNAJB1, was overexpressed. The study suggests that Sis1 and its homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS and related conditions characterized by cytoplasmic mislocalization and aggregation of DNA/RNA binding proteins such as TDP-43. The researchers propose that overexpression of Sis1 or its homologues may be a potential means of extending neuronal survival in ALS. The study's findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying ALS and highlight the potential of Hsp40 chaperones as therapeutic targets for the disease.
Researchers conducted a study to investigate the parasite load and molecular diversity of Trypanosoma cruzi in patients with chronic Chagas disease from different regions of Brazil. A total of 65 patients were recruited, with 35 (53.8%) testing positive for the parasite using real-time quantitative PCR (qPCR). The parasite load was significantly higher in patients over 70 years old, with a median of 20.05 parasite equivalents per milliliter (par.Eq./mL). The parasite load ranged from 0.12 to 153.66 par.Eq./mL, with a median of 2.54 par.Eq./mL for all positive patients.

The researchers used a multilocus conventional PCR and qPCR approach to genotype the parasite and identify the discrete typing units (DTUs) of T. cruzi. Of the patients with positive qPCR, 80% were able to identify the DTU, with 40% infected with TcVI, 17.1% with TcII, and 14.3% with a mixed infection of TcVI and TcII. Two patients were infected with TcV, and one patient was co-infected with TcIII and TcVI. The parasite load was higher in patients infected with TcII compared to those infected with TcVI.

The study highlights the importance of age and DTU in determining the parasite load and clinical manifestations of Chagas disease. The results contribute to the epidemiological knowledge of T. cruzi DTUs in Brazil and suggest that TcII infection is associated with higher parasite loads and a lower frequency of chronic chagasic cardiomyopathy (CCC).
A study on bat rabies in Guatemala was conducted between 2009 and 2011 as part of a larger pathogen detection program. A total of 672 bats from 31 species were sampled and tested for rabies virus (RABV). The overall prevalence of RABV detection among all collected bats was low, at 0.3%. However, two common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus) were found to be infected with RABV, with viral antigens detected and infectious virus isolated from their brains, as well as from oral swabs, lungs, and kidneys. Sequencing of the nucleoprotein gene showed that the two viruses were 100% identical, while sequencing of the glycoprotein gene revealed a single non-synonymous substitution. The two vampire bat RABV isolates were phylogenetically related to viruses associated with vampire bats in eastern Mexico and El Salvador. Additionally, 7% of sera collected from 398 bats demonstrated RABV neutralizing antibody, indicating exposure to the virus. The proportion of seropositive bats varied significantly across trophic guilds, suggesting complex intraspecific compartmentalization of RABV perpetuation. This study is the first to report and isolate RABV from bats in Guatemala, highlighting the need for novel strategies to prevent and control bat-associated zoonoses in tropical regions.
Researchers investigated the role of A-type lamins in herpesviral DNA targeting and heterochromatin modulation. They found that A-type lamins play a crucial role in the downregulation of heterochromatin and the activation of gene expression. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) DNA initiates replication in replication compartments near the inner edge of the nucleus, where histones are excluded. In cells lacking A-type lamins (Lmna−/−), viral replication compartments are reduced in size and fail to target to the nuclear periphery. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and immunofluorescence studies showed that HSV DNA is associated with increased heterochromatin in Lmna−/− cells. This suggests that A-type lamins are necessary for targeting the viral genome and reducing heterochromatin on viral promoters during lytic infection. The study found that lamin A/C is required for viral gene expression, DNA replication, and growth, with the greatest effect on viral replication at low multiplicity of infection. The results indicate that the nuclear lamina can serve as a molecular scaffold for DNA genomes and the protein complexes that regulate both euchromatin and heterochromatin histone modifications. The study provides evidence that lamin-dependent targeting of the HSV genome to the nuclear periphery is associated with a reduction of heterochromatin on viral lytic genes. The findings suggest that the nuclear lamina plays a role in providing a platform for recruitment of viral DNA and chromatin-modifying enzymes that keep the viral genome in an active chromatin conformation.
Researchers have investigated the structure and function of the translocase of the outer membrane (TOM) complex in hydrogenosomes, a type of mitochondria found in the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. Hydrogenosomes are metabolically specialized anaerobic organelles that are thought to have originated from proteobacterial endosymbionts. The TOM complex plays a crucial role in the import of proteins into mitochondria, but its structure and function have been poorly understood in many eukaryotic lineages.

The study found that the TOM complex in T. vaginalis, called TvTOM, forms a translocation channel to conduct protein import into hydrogenosomes. TvTOM is composed of four subunits, including two tail-anchored proteins, Tom36 and Tom46, which can bind hydrogenosomal preproteins and function as receptors. A third subunit, Tom22-like protein, has a short cis domain and a conserved Tom22 transmembrane segment, but lacks a trans domain. The fourth protein, hydrogenosomal outer membrane protein 19 (Homp19), has no known homology.

Electron microscopy revealed that TvTOM forms three pores and has an unconventional skull-like shape. The study suggests that the triplet-pore TOM complex, composed of three conserved subunits, was present in the last common eukaryotic ancestor (LECA), while receptors responsible for substrate binding evolved independently in different eukaryotic lineages. The findings provide new insights into the evolution and function of the TOM complex in eukaryotic cells.
Researchers have investigated the role of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells in autoimmune diseases, such as multiple sclerosis and type 1 diabetes. They used a technique called eQTL (expression quantitative trait locus) analysis to study how genetic variations affect the expression of genes in these cells. This approach allowed them to identify specific genetic variants associated with autoimmune diseases, including a trans-acting regulatory locus at chromosome 12q13.2 that contains a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in the RPS26 gene.

The study found that a common missense variant in the IL27 gene, which is associated with type 1 diabetes, results in decreased functional activity of the protein and reduced expression levels of downstream genes IRF1 and STAT1 in CD4+ T cells. This suggests that the variant may confer protection against type 1 diabetes by inhibiting the expression of these genes. In contrast, the study also found that IL-27 may promote autoimmunity towards pancreatic islets via the upregulation of the STAT1 pathway.

The researchers also identified a distinct lineage of CD4+ T cells, regulatory T cells, which play a central role in controlling the pathogenesis of autoimmune and inflammatory diseases. Genome-wide association studies have previously identified thousands of SNPs associated with various immune-related diseases. The study's eQTL mapping in purified CD4+ and CD8+ T cells revealed multiple effects on the regulation of genes associated with autoimmune diseases, highlighting the importance of cell-type specificity in understanding the genetic regulation of the immune system.
A qualitative study was conducted in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) to investigate community perspectives on the treatment of Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT), also known as sleeping sickness. The study aimed to understand the socio-cultural and economic factors that hinder the uptake of screening and treatment of HAT in the DRC. Semi-structured interviews and focus group discussions were conducted with current and former HAT patients, healthcare providers, and program managers of the national HAT control program in the Bandundu and Kasaï Oriental provinces, where HAT prevalence is high.

The study found that community members and healthcare providers adhere to strict prohibitions after HAT treatment, including avoiding work, sexual intercourse, hot food, and walking in the sun for six months. These prohibitions are believed to prevent serious and potentially deadly complications, but are not evidence-based and were originally intended to mitigate the adverse effects of the outdated melarsoprol regimen. However, with the introduction of safer and more effective treatment options, such as nifurtimox-eflornithine combination therapy (NECT), these restrictions may no longer be necessary.

The study highlights the importance of addressing community perceptions and attitudes towards HAT treatment to improve control efforts. The prohibitions associated with HAT treatment are a significant barrier to community participation in screening and treatment activities, compromising the national control program's ability to achieve its objectives. Understanding the origins and rationale behind these prohibitions is essential to develop effective HAT control strategies in the DRC.
A cross-sectional survey was conducted in 45 villages of Al-Gureisha locality in eastern Gedaref State, Sudan, to estimate the incidence of visceral leishmaniasis (VL). The survey, conducted between May and June 2011, involved door-to-door interviews with 17,702 households, representing a population of 94,369 inhabitants. The crude mortality rate over the mean recall period of 409 days was 0.13/10,000 people per day, with VL being a possible or probable cause for 19% of all deaths. The VL-specific mortality rate was estimated at 0.9/1000 per year.

The overall incidence of VL over the past year was 7.0/1000 persons per year, or 7.9/1000 per year when deaths possibly or probably due to VL were included. A total of 12.5% (11,943/95,609) of the population reported a past VL treatment episode. The survey found that active VL case detection had a very low yield in this specific setting with adequate access to care, suggesting that it may not be the priority intervention to enhance control in similar contexts.

Visceral leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania donovani and L. infantum, transmitted by phlebotomine sand flies. It mainly affects areas in South Asia and Eastern Africa, with Sudan being the most affected country. The disease is characterized by persistent fever, splenomegaly, weight loss, and lymphadenopathies, and can lead to post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL), a skin rash that appears after treatment and can last for months or years.
Researchers investigated the relationship between DNA supercoiling and transcription elongation in bacterial chromosomes. They found that the supercoil density (σ) of Escherichia coli (E. coli) chromosomes is 15% higher than that of Salmonella enterica. The supercoil density is composed of two forms: diffusible supercoil density (σD) and constrained supercoil density (σC). The study used a 9 kb "supercoil sensor" to monitor supercoil density and transcription elongation rates in Salmonella strains. The results showed that RNA transcription causes negative supercoiling to increase upstream and decrease downstream of highly expressed genes. Topoisomerase I (Topo I) relaxes excess upstream supercoiling, while gyrase replenishes downstream supercoil losses to maintain an equilibrium state. Mutations in the gyrase gene (gyrB) caused significant supercoil losses, ranging from 30% to a total loss of σD at most chromosome locations. These losses were influenced by transcription, as adding rifampicin (Rif) caused supercoil density to rebound throughout the chromosome. The study also found a link between RNA polymerase elongation speed and gyrase turnover, suggesting that bacteria with fast growth rates may generate higher supercoil densities than slow-growing species. The results indicate that the mean supercoil density of Salmonella DNA is determined by a mechanism that links the catalytic efficiency of gyrase to the elongation rate of transcription.
Leishmania amazonensis, a protozoan parasite, replicates within parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) in host cells, which share characteristics with late endosomes and lysosomes. Research has shown that the size of PVs expands significantly during infections, but the impact of PV size on parasite intracellular survival was unknown. This study found that host cells infected with L. amazonensis upregulate the transcription of the LYST/Beige gene, which regulates lysosome size. Mutations in LYST/Beige led to further PV expansion and enhanced L. amazonensis replication, while overexpression of LYST/Beige resulted in small PVs that did not sustain parasite growth. Treatment of LYST/Beige overexpressing cells with vacuolin-1 reversed this phenotype, expanding PVs and promoting parasite growth. In contrast, E-64d reduced PV size in LYST-Beige mutant cells and inhibited L. amazonensis replication. The study suggests that enlarged PVs protect parasites from oxidative damage, as inhibition of nitric oxide synthase had no effect on L. amazonensis viability within large PVs, but enhanced their growth within LYST/Beige-induced small PVs. These findings indicate that the upregulation of LYST/Beige in infected cells functions as a host innate response to limit parasite growth by reducing PV volume and inhibiting intracellular survival.
Researchers investigated the mechanisms underlying psychomotor retardation, a condition characterized by motor and cognitive impairment, using a zebrafish model. The study focused on the Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome (AHDS), an X-linked disorder associated with mutations in the monocarboxylate transporter 8 (MCT8) gene, which plays a crucial role in thyroid hormone (TH) transport. Previous studies using MCT8 knockout mice failed to replicate the neurological and behavioral symptoms of AHDS patients, despite altered TH levels. To address this discrepancy, the researchers generated an MCT8 mutant (mct8−/−) zebrafish using zinc-finger nuclease-mediated targeted gene editing. The mct8−/− larvae exhibited neurological and behavioral deficiencies, including reduced locomotor activity, altered response to light and dark transitions, and increased sleep time. High-throughput behavioral assays revealed altered expression of myelin-related genes and neuron-specific deficiencies in circuit formation. Live imaging of single-axon arbors and synapses in mct8−/− larvae showed reduced filopodia dynamics and axon branching in sensory neurons, as well as decreased synaptic density in motor neurons. Treatment with TH analogs that can enter cells in the absence of MCT8 restored myelin and axon outgrowth deficiencies in mct8−/− larvae. These findings suggest that MCT8 regulates neural circuit assembly and mediates sensory and motor control of behavioral performance. The study proposes that early administration of TH analogs may reduce neurological damage in AHDS patients.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a widespread virus that primarily affects newborns and individuals with weakened immune systems. The virus uses distinct entry pathways to infect various cell types, involving different forms of the gH/gL glycoprotein complex. Research has shown that the minimal fusion machinery required for cell-cell fusion involves only the gH/gL and gB glycoproteins. A recent study has demonstrated that HCMV gB and gH/gL form a stable complex early in the virus's life cycle, even in the absence of other viral proteins. This complex includes up to 16-50% of the total gH/gL in HCMV virus particles. The study also found that gH/gL can interact with gB mutants that are unable to mediate cell-cell fusion, suggesting that the interaction between gB and gH/gL is not dependent on the fusion activity of gB. These findings have significant implications for models of herpesvirus entry, which suggest that gH/gL interacts with gB to mediate membrane fusion. The study's results provide direct evidence for this interaction, showing that HCMV gB and gH/gL form stable complexes that are incorporated into virions without the need for receptor binding or membrane fusion.
Researchers have identified a new gene, Gimap3, that plays a crucial role in regulating the segregation of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in leukocytes. Mitochondrial DNA sequence variants can lead to disease, and understanding how they segregate is essential for understanding disease onset and severity. The study used a heteroplasmic mouse model to demonstrate that Gimap3, an outer mitochondrial membrane GTPase, is a critical regulator of mtDNA segregation in leukocytes. Gimap3 is also important for T cell development and survival, suggesting that leukocyte survival may be a key factor in the genetic regulation of mtDNA sequence variants and in modulating human mitochondrial diseases.

The study found that Gimap3 regulates the rate of mtDNA segregation in hematopoietic tissues and that segregation of mtDNA haplotypes in mouse hematopoietic tissues is a complex genetic trait regulated with age but independent of mtDNA copy number. Analysis of the Gimap3 protein sequence did not reveal a direct physical interaction with mtDNA, suggesting that a cell-specific context or pathway is required to alter mtDNA segregation. The study also found that mitochondrial genome copy number regulation has been proposed to influence the segregation of mtDNA haplotypes and human mtDNA mutations. Overall, the discovery of Gimap3 as a regulator of mtDNA segregation in leukocytes provides new insights into the genetic regulation of mtDNA sequence variants and has implications for understanding human mitochondrial diseases.
Researchers studied the incubation period of Buruli ulcer (BU), a skin and soft-tissue infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans, in Victoria, Australia. The incubation period is the time between exposure to the bacteria and the onset of symptoms. The study found that the mean incubation period of BU in Victoria is approximately 4-5 months, with a range of 2-9 months. This estimate is consistent with a previous study of patients who acquired the infection in a different geographic location. The researchers analyzed data from 443 cases of BU notified in Victoria between 2013 and 2016, including 20 new cases identified in short-term visitors to endemic regions. The study found no association between incubation period and age, sex, location of exposure, duration of exposure to an endemic region, or location of the BU lesion. The results suggest that the mode of transmission of BU is similar in different geographic regions in Victoria. This knowledge can guide clinicians in diagnosing and treating the disease. The study's findings are significant because BU is a geographically-restricted infection, and delayed diagnosis is common among non-residents of endemic areas. Understanding the incubation period can help raise awareness and improve public health responses to the disease.
Researchers have identified a protein in the parasite Toxoplasma gondii that is related to the Niemann-Pick, type C1 (NPC1) protein found in humans. This protein, named TgNCR1, contains a sterol-sensing domain (SSD) and shares significant identity with human NPC1, which is involved in cholesterol synthesis, regulation, trafficking, and signaling. TgNCR1 localizes to flattened vesicles beneath the plasma membrane of Toxoplasma, rather than endo-lysosomes like its human counterpart. When expressed in mammalian cells lacking NPC1, TgNCR1 restores cholesterol and GM1 clearance from endo-lysosomes, indicating a conserved activity with human NPC1.

To investigate the role of TgNCR1 in Toxoplasma, the researchers genetically disrupted the NCR1 gene and analyzed the resulting mutant parasites. They found that the ΔNCR1 strain had normal cholesterol levels but overaccumulated several species of cholesteryl esters, sphingomyelins, and ceramides. The mutant parasites also exhibited abundant storage lipid bodies and long membranous tubules derived from their parasitophorous vacuoles. Notably, the ΔNCR1 strain was more virulent in mice than the parental strain and could generate multiple daughters per single mother cell at high frequencies, allowing for fast replication in vitro.

These findings suggest that TgNCR1 plays a role in lipid homeostasis in Toxoplasma, controlling the intracellular levels of several lipids and regulating lipid storage, membrane biosynthesis, and parasite division.
Ophthalmo-acromelic syndrome (OAS), also known as Waardenburg anophthalmia syndrome, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by eye malformations, most commonly bilateral anophthalmia, and post-axial oligosyndactyly. Recent studies have identified homozygous mutations in the SMOC1 gene in eight unrelated families, which is associated with the development of OAS. The SMOC1 gene encodes a protein that functions as a Bone Morphogenic Protein (BMP) antagonist during embryonic development. Loss of BMP antagonism is thought to contribute to the limb and eye phenotypes observed in humans and mice with OAS. A targeted pre-conditional gene-trap mutation of the orthologous mouse gene, Smoc1, resulted in highly penetrant hindlimb post-axial oligosyndactyly and eye malformations, including coloboma and cleft palate, in homozygous mutant animals. These findings suggest that partial loss of Smoc-1 results in a convincing phenocopy of the human disease. The SMOC1 gene is one of the two mammalian paralogs of Drosophila Pentagone, an inhibitor of decapentaplegic. The orthologous gene in Xenopus laevis, Smoc-1, also functions as a BMP antagonist in early embryogenesis, further supporting the conserved non-redundant function of SMOC-1 during ocular and limb development.
Researchers have identified a protein called TRIM22 as a key mediator of the interferon response, which restricts HIV replication in human cells. Interferons are proteins that are produced by cells in response to viral infections, and they play a crucial role in the body's defense against viruses, including HIV. The study found that TRIM22 is one of the most strongly up-regulated genes in response to interferon treatment, and that over-expression of TRIM22 inhibits HIV replication. The researchers used RNA interference (RNAi) to deplete TRIM22 in cells treated with interferon and found that HIV particle release was significantly increased in the absence of TRIM22, suggesting that TRIM22 acts as a natural antiviral effector. Further studies showed that TRIM22 specifically targets the HIV Gag protein, which is essential for the assembly and release of the virus. The researchers found that TRIM22 disrupts the proper trafficking of the Gag protein, preventing it from reaching the plasma membrane where it is needed for virus assembly and budding. Mutational analyses revealed that the catalytic amino acids Cys15 and Cys18 of the RING domain of TRIM22 are required for its antiviral activity. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms by which interferons inhibit HIV replication and highlight the potential of TRIM22 as a target for the development of new antiviral therapies.
Researchers have investigated the stability of the fig-pollinator mutualism, a symbiotic relationship between fig trees (Ficus) and their host-specific pollinator wasps (Agaonidae). In this mutualism, wasps pollinate the trees and receive resources for their offspring in return. However, the stability of this relationship is puzzling, as "cheater" wasps should outcompete cooperative conspecifics, leading to mutualism instability. A study on Ficus rubiginosa found that offspring in outer ovules are vulnerable to attack by parasitic wasps that oviposit from outside the syconium, while inner ovules provide enemy-free space for pollinator offspring. This gradient in offspring viability may contribute to selection on pollinators to avoid outer ovules, reducing their galling rates and promoting mutualism stability. The study suggests that parasitic wasps may play a previously unidentified role in maintaining the fig-pollinator mutualism by forcing pollinators to focus on a subset of ovules. This mechanism may contribute to mutualism persistence independently of plant defenses against pollinator oviposition or physiological constraints on pollinators. The study provides new insights into the complex dynamics of the fig-pollinator mutualism and highlights the importance of considering the role of parasitic wasps in maintaining this symbiotic relationship. The findings have implications for understanding the evolution and maintenance of mutualisms in general.
Researchers conducted six controlled growth trials on an interspecific Setaria italica x Setaria viridis recombinant inbred line population to investigate how genetic and environmental factors influence plant height. The study found that plant height is a heritable, polygenic trait that is affected by water availability, planting density, and growth environment. The results suggest that plant height is a functionally continuous developmental process that is under strong genetic control but can be influenced by environmental factors.

The study used a combination of field and controlled environmental analysis to dissect the genetic and environmental components of plant height in Setaria. The researchers identified 37 quantitative trait loci (QTL) associated with plant height throughout development within the RIL population across 12 different experiments varying water availability and planting density. Analysis of ortholog positions suggests that known height-affecting genes from the Poaceae family account for only a fraction of the identified loci.

The study found that alleles inherited from the weedy S. viridis parent act to increase plant height early in development, while a larger number of small-effect alleles inherited from the domesticated S. italica parent collectively act to increase plant height later in development. The results support a chronological genetic model of plant height, where the contribution of genetic loci is influenced by temporal and environmental factors. This model may explain the differences in plant height observed when parental lines are grown in controlled environments versus field settings.
A recent study conducted in the Nhecolândia sub-region of the Brazilian Pantanal has confirmed the presence of Ilheus virus (ILHV) in the region. The Pantanal, a vast wetland area, is home to a diverse range of wildlife species and hematophagous arthropods, creating an environment conducive to the circulation of zoonotic arboviruses. Previous studies had detected neutralizing antibodies to various flaviviruses, including ILHV, in horses from the area, but virus isolation had not been confirmed. To investigate further, researchers collected and tested 3,234 adult mosquitoes from 16 species in 2009 and 2010. One pool of 50 non-engorged female Aedes scapularis mosquitoes tested positive for ILHV by culture and real-time RT-PCR, indicating a minimum infection rate of 2.5 per 1,000. The full-length genomic sequence of the isolated virus showed 95% identity to the only available full genome sequence for ILHV. This finding confirms the circulation of ILHV in the Brazilian Pantanal. The study highlights the potential medical importance of ILHV in the region and warrants further investigation by the Brazilian arbovirus surveillance program and local physicians.
A preclinical study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics of single-dose moxidectin (MOX) compared to two-dose ivermectin (IVM) in a porcine scabies model. Twelve pigs were randomly assigned to receive either MOX (0.3 mg/kg once), IVM (0.2 mg/kg twice), or no treatment. Treatment efficacy was assessed by evaluating mite count, clinical lesions, pruritus, and ELISA-determined anti-S. scabiei IgG antibodies reductions. At day 14 post-treatment, all four MOX-treated pigs were mite-free, while only two IVM-treated pigs were mite-free. MOX efficacy was 100% and remained unchanged until study-end (D47), compared to 62% for IVM. Clinical scabies lesions, pruritus, and anti-S. scabiei IgG antibodies had completely disappeared in all MOX-treated but only 75% of IVM-treated pigs. MOX persisted ~9 times longer than IVM in plasma and skin, enabling long-lasting efficacy. The study demonstrates that oral single-dose MOX was more effective than two consecutive IVM-doses, supporting MOX as a potential therapeutic approach for scabies. The findings suggest that MOX may be a promising alternative to current treatments, which are often insufficient and may lead to drug resistance. Further studies are needed to investigate the efficacy and dose selection of MOX in humans.
Researchers studied the peptidoglycan (PG) synthesis machine in Staphylococcus aureus, a Gram-positive pathogen known for its antibiotic resistance and prevalence in hospitals. The PG synthesis machine is responsible for synthesizing the main component of the bacterial cell wall and is the target of many antibiotics. By deleting seven of the nine genes encoding PG synthesis enzymes from the S. aureus genome, the researchers created a strain capable of PG biosynthesis catalyzed only by two penicillin-binding proteins, PBP1 and the bi-functional PBP2. This minimal PG synthesis machinery allowed the bacteria to grow and divide normally in vitro. However, in clinically relevant environments, the bacteria became highly susceptible to cell wall-targeting antibiotics and host lytic enzymes, and displayed impaired virulence in a Drosophila infection model. This suggests that the expendable PG synthesis enzymes play an important role in the pathogenicity and antibiotic resistance of S. aureus.
