An IKAROS mutant unable to bind PP1α cannot sustain gene expression and impairs normal differentiation of hematopoietic progenitors. Furthermore, the study reveals that the occupancy of the NuRD complex at transcribed regions of genes favors the relief of POL II promoter-proximal pausing and promotes transcription elongation.

The results suggest that IKAROS is the DNA-binding subunit of the NuRD-P-TEFb multifunctional complex, which contains chromatin remodeling and gene transcription elongation activities. IKAROS is essential for CDK9 and Mi2 interaction and combined recruitment to actively transcribed genes in hematopoietic cells. The study provides mechanistic insights into the central role played by IKAROS as a transcriptional activator during hematopoietic lineage decision, differentiation, and interaction with the niche.
This study investigated the evolutionary history and phylogeography of rabies viruses associated with outbreaks in Trinidad, a Caribbean island. The researchers characterized Trinidadian rabies virus (RABV) sequences and used a Bayesian phylogeographic approach to determine whether outbreaks were caused by in situ evolution or the importation of virus from the nearby South American mainland. The study found that Trinidadian RABV sequences belonged to the bat-associated Clade 2 and clustered into three largely temporally defined lineages: Trinidad I, IIa, and IIb. These lineages were most closely related to RABV sequences from Ecuador, French Guiana, Venezuela, Brazil, and Uruguay. Phylogeographic analyses suggested that there were three separate RABV introductions from the mainland, from which each of the three Trinidadian lineages arose. The estimated dates for the introductions and subsequent lineage expansions indicate periods of in situ evolution within Trinidad following each introduction. The study also found evidence of co-circulation of Trinidad lineage I and IIa during 2000. The results suggest that further studies should be conducted to investigate the relationship between RABV spatiotemporal dynamics and vampire bat population ecology, particularly any movement between the mainland and Trinidad. The study highlights the importance of monitoring bat species with migratory habits to determine if RABV variants different from those associated with vampire bats are also being introduced into Trinidad.
Researchers developed a computational model to study the gene regulatory network underlying the development of distinct areas in the mammalian cerebral cortex. The model focused on five genes: Fgf8, Emx2, Pax6, Coup-tfi, and Sp8, which play a crucial role in specifying areal identity along the anterior-posterior axis. The model treated expression levels as Boolean, reflecting the qualitative nature of the available expression data. By simulating all possible networks containing these five genes, the researchers found that only a subset of networks were able to reproduce the experimentally observed expression patterns. These networks lacked certain interactions, including auto-regulation and inductive loops. The analysis revealed that repressive interactions are more likely than inductive ones, but mutually repressive loops are not critical for correct network functioning. The model suggests that Fgf8 expression at the anterior pole may be sufficient to drive the correct spatial patterning of the transcription factors Emx2, Pax6, Coup-tfi, and Sp8, if simple interactions between these transcription factors exist. The study provides insights into the design principles of the gene network regulating cortical area development and makes novel predictions that can be tested experimentally.
Researchers used a technique called ChIP-Seq to study the distribution of a specific histone modification called ubiquitylated H2A (uH2A) across the genome in mouse cells. This modification is associated with the Polycomb group (PcG) proteins, which play a crucial role in regulating gene expression during development. The study focused on Bmi1, a component of the PcG complex, and its role in depositing uH2A at repressed genes. The results showed that Bmi1-dependent uH2A is enriched at gene promoters, particularly those containing the H3K27me3 mark, which is another histone modification associated with gene silencing. However, uH2A is not limited to these regions and is also found at high-density CpG promoters, where it is linked to DNA methylation. The study found that genes with uH2A peaks exhibit lower expression levels compared to those without uH2A peaks, and that Bmi1 knockout leads to increased expression of genes with uH2A peaks. This suggests that Bmi1-dependent uH2A plays a role in repressing gene expression. The study also found that DNA methylation may be upstream of Bmi1-dependent H2A ubiquitylation, and that uH2A targeting in differentiated cells may employ a different mechanism than in embryonic stem cells. Overall, the study provides new insights into the role of Bmi1-dependent uH2A in gene regulation and its relationship with other epigenetic modifications.
Researchers investigated the role of pregnancy-induced noncoding RNA (PINC) in regulating mammary epithelial cell differentiation during pregnancy and lactation. They found that PINC is highly expressed in alveolar cells of the mammary gland during pregnancy and decreases in early lactation, when alveolar cells undergo terminal differentiation to produce milk proteins. This reduction in PINC levels may be necessary for lactation, as overexpression of PINC in mammary epithelial cells blocks lactogenic differentiation, while knockdown of PINC enhances differentiation. PINC interacts with the retinoblastoma-associated protein 46 (RbAp46) and other members of the polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2), which may confer epigenetic modifications that maintain a population of mammary epithelial cells committed to the alveolar fate in the involuted gland. The study suggests that PINC inhibits terminal differentiation of alveolar cells during pregnancy to prevent abundant milk production and secretion until parturition. Additionally, the PRC2 complex that includes PINC and RbAp46 may play a role in maintaining a population of mammary epithelial cells that are committed to the alveolar fate in the involuted gland. These findings provide new insights into the regulation of mammary epithelial cell differentiation during pregnancy and lactation.
Researchers have investigated the role of PML/TRIM19 in antiviral defense, specifically its effect on HIV-1 infection. They found that HIV-1 and other retroviruses trigger the formation of PML cytoplasmic bodies as early as 30 minutes post-infection. These bodies last approximately 8 hours, with a peak at 2 hours post-infection. PML re-localization is blocked by reverse-transcription inhibitors and is not observed following infection with unrelated viruses, suggesting it is specifically triggered by retroviral reverse-transcription. PML knockdown dramatically increases reverse-transcription efficiency, indicating that PML interferes with an early step of retroviral infection. However, PML does not directly inhibit retroviral infection, but rather acts through the stabilization of its partner protein, Daxx. Daxx is found in the vicinity of incoming HIV-1 capsids and inhibits reverse-transcription. Daxx not only interferes with exogenous retroviral infections but also inhibits retrotransposition of endogenous retroviruses, identifying Daxx as a broad cellular inhibitor of reverse-transcription. This study reveals a novel antiviral function for PML and its associated protein Daxx, highlighting their role in restricting retroviral infections.
Researchers have developed a new program, Matt, to improve protein multiple structure alignment, a crucial step in understanding protein function and evolution. Current methods often rely on aligned fragment pair chaining, where short structural fragments are aligned optimally and then chained together. However, this approach can be computationally prohibitive. Matt introduces local flexibility between fragments, allowing small translations and rotations to bring aligned fragments closer, even if they are physically impossible under rigid body transformations. This flexibility is temporarily allowed in intermediate steps, and geometric consistency is restored in the final step.

Matt was tested against other recent multiple protein structure alignment programs on the Homstrad and SABmark benchmark datasets. On Homstrad, a dataset of highly homologous proteins, Matt's performance was competitive with other programs. However, on SABmark, a dataset of proteins with more distant homology, Matt outperformed other programs, particularly in aligning the ends of alpha-helices and beta-strands. This is an important characteristic for constructing a structural template library for threading approaches to the inverse protein-folding problem.

Matt's ability to model proteins in different conformational states and backbone distortions in more distantly related proteins is thought to contribute to its strong performance. Additionally, a p-value score based on the length of the common core and average root mean squared deviation (RMSD) of Matt alignments was able to distinguish distantly homologous structure pairs from non-homologous pairs in the SABmark dataset.
Researchers investigated the regulation of Greatwall (Gwl) kinase and its substrates, Ensa and ARPP19, during mitotic exit in cells. Gwl inactivates the phosphatase PP2A/B55, which normally counteracts the activity of the kinase Cdk1. However, the dynamic regulation of Gwl activity and the phosphatases that control Gwl kinase and its substrates were poorly understood. The study used a combination of mathematical modeling and experiments to monitor the phosphorylation of Gwl, Ensa/ARPP19, and Cdk substrates during mitotic entry and exit. The results showed that PP2A/B55 is required for the dephosphorylation of Gwl at a critical site, and that the RNA Polymerase II carboxy-terminal domain phosphatase Fcp1 mediates the dephosphorylation of Ensa/ARPP19. Surprisingly, inhibiting or depleting Fcp1 or PP2A did not block the dephosphorylation of most Cdk1 substrates during mitotic exit. The study suggests a hierarchy of phosphatases that coordinate the dephosphorylation of Gwl, Ensa/ARPP19, and Cdk substrates during mitotic exit. The findings provide new insights into the regulation of mitotic exit and the role of phosphatases in this process. The study also highlights the complexity of the phosphatase network that counteracts Gwl, Ensa/ARPP19, and Cdk phosphorylation during mitotic exit.
Researchers investigated the development of neutralizing antibodies (Nab) in two individuals with acute/early subtype C HIV-1 infection. Despite the presence of high-titer autologous Nab, the virus was able to escape neutralization through multiple pathways. In one subject, escape was driven primarily by changes in the V3V5 region of the envelope glycoprotein, while in the other subject, escape was driven by changes in the V1V2 region. Notably, the virus in the second subject was able to evade two distinct monoclonal antibodies by introducing a single potential N-linked glycosylation site in V2. Spatial analysis of the sequence changes in gp120 revealed that selective pressure acted on the same regions of Env in both subjects, despite the different escape pathways used. The findings suggest that a single mutational pathway is not sufficient to confer escape in early subtype C HIV-1 infection, and that multiple strategies, including glycan shifts, direct alteration of epitope sequences, and cooperative Env domain conformational masking, are used to evade neutralization. These results have implications for the development of an effective HIV vaccine, which aims to elicit Nab that can limit replication of genetically diverse viruses and prevent establishment of a new infection.
Researchers analyzed the genomes of 13 individuals of the plant species Capsella grandiflora to understand the extent of positive and negative selection across different parts of the genome. They found that selection is strong in coding regions, but weak in most noncoding regions, except for 5' and 3' untranslated regions (UTRs). However, when looking at noncoding regions that are conserved across the Brassicaceae family, they detected strong signals of selection. Additionally, the team observed reduced genetic diversity around functional substitutions in both coding and conserved noncoding regions, indicating recent selective sweeps at these sites. They also found that genes with higher expression levels experience stronger negative selection but similar levels of positive selection compared to genes with lower expression levels. Overall, the study reveals widespread positive and negative selection in coding and regulatory regions, but suggests that both types of selection are less common in plant noncoding sequences compared to animal genomes. The findings have implications for understanding genome function and the maintenance of genetic variation.
Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)-encoded transcriptional regulator EBNA2 plays a crucial role in transforming resting B-lymphocytes into proliferating lymphoblasts, which can lead to malignancies. Research has shown that EBNA2 drives the cooperative and combinatorial genome-wide binding of two master regulators of B-cell fate, EBF1 and RBP-jκ. Unlike previous studies, which suggested that these B-cell factors are statically bound to target gene promoters, EBNA2 induces the formation of new binding sites for both RBP-jκ and EBF1, many of which are in close physical proximity in the cellular and viral genome. These newly induced binding sites co-occupied by EBNA2-EBF1-RBP-jκ correlate strongly with the transcriptional activation of linked genes important for B-lymphoblast function. Conditional expression or repression of EBNA2 leads to a rapid alteration in RBP-jκ and EBF1 binding. Biochemical and shRNA depletion studies provide evidence for cooperative assembly at co-occupied sites. EBNA2 facilitates combinatorial interactions to induce new patterns of transcription factor occupancy and gene programming necessary to drive B-lymphoblast growth and survival. EBV type III latency promotes a B-cell marginal zone developmental program, increasing the number of RBP-jκ binding sites. EBNA2 reprograms the chromosome binding patterns of host master regulatory transcription factors RBP-jκ and EBF1.
Aedes aegypti, the primary mosquito vector of dengue virus, exhibits significant genetic structure and variation in vector competence (VC) for dengue serotype 2 virus (DENV2) in Mexico. Population genetic studies have identified the Neovolcanic axis (NVA) as a discrete barrier to gene flow among Ae. aegypti populations north and south of the NVA in the state of Veracruz. Mosquito populations from north and south of the NVA differ in their VC for DENV2, with an average VC rate of 0.55 for mosquitoes from north of the NVA and 0.20 for those from south of the NVA. The variation in VC is primarily due to midgut infection and escape barriers, with 21.5% of mosquitoes from north of the NVA failing to develop midgut infections and 30.3% of those with an infected midgut failing to develop a disseminated infection. In contrast, 45.2% of mosquitoes from south of the NVA failed to develop midgut infections and 62.8% of those with an infected midgut failed to develop a disseminated infection. The NVA may impact the frequency of genes that condition continuous and epidemiologically relevant traits such as VC. Further studies are needed to determine why the NVA acts as a barrier to gene flow and whether the differences in VC between north and south of the NVA are stable and epidemiologically significant.
Researchers investigated the role of the DnaA protein in the initiation of DNA replication in Escherichia coli (E. coli) cells. The DnaA protein cycles between an active ATP-bound form and an inactive ADP-bound form, and it has been suggested that it is the main controller of initiation frequency. However, the study found that increasing the concentration of ATP-DnaA by more than 50% did not affect the timing of replication initiation in E. coli cells. This suggests that the DnaA protein is not the limiting factor for the precise timing of initiation of replication.

The researchers propose that the DnaA protein is the motor that drives the initiation process, but other factors are required for the exact timing of initiation in response to the cell's environment. They also investigated the in vivo roles of DDAH (DnaA-dependent DnaA inactivation) and the DnaA-binding protein DiaA, and found that loss of DDAH affected the cell cycle machinery only during slow growth and made it sensitive to the concentration of DiaA protein.

The study suggests that E. coli has a robust replication cycle driven by the cycling of the levels of ATP-DnaA and ADP-DnaA, and that initiation cannot occur unless sufficient amounts of ATP-DnaA at the origin of replication (oriC) have licensed this event. The researchers propose that signals depending on the cell's environment govern the exact timing of initiation, and that the frequency of replication must match the growth rate to maintain a stable cellular DNA concentration.
Researchers have developed a novel approach called partial Granger causality to uncover interactions in complex biological systems. This method is designed to reveal interaction patterns in multivariate data with exogenous inputs and latent variables in the frequency domain. The approach was tested using toy models and applied to experimental datasets, including gene microarray data from HeLa cells, in vivo local field potentials from the sheep's inferotemporal cortex, and in vivo LFPs from the macaque monkey's right hemisphere.

The study aimed to demonstrate that traditional definitions of causality, such as partial directed coherence (PDC) in the frequency domain, can be misleading and yield contradictory results compared to time-domain Granger causality. The researchers found that partial Granger causality in the frequency domain can provide a more accurate representation of causal relationships in complex systems.

The method was applied to a toy model with exogenous inputs and latent variables, which showed that the definition of partial Granger causality has a transparent statistical meaning based on conditional variance. The approach was also applied to experimental data from a macaque monkey performing a visual pattern discrimination task, where the presence of oscillatory field potential activity in the beta frequency range was reported in the sensorimotor cortex during the prestimulus period. The results showed that partial Granger causality in the frequency domain can reveal the complete causal relationship between variables, including the influence of latent variables and exogenous inputs.
Researchers have developed new methods for determining the ancestry of specific regions of the genome in individuals with mixed ancestry, such as Latino Americans. This information is crucial for medical and population genetic studies, as it can help identify disease-risk loci, infer recombination rates, and map missing contigs in the human genome. However, existing methods for local ancestry inference are often designed for use with genotyping arrays and fail to utilize the full range of data available from sequencing.

The new approach, called Lanc-CSV, leverages continent-specific variants (CSVs) to improve performance in sequenced admixed genomes. This method incorporates both the admixed genomes themselves and public datasets, such as the 1000 Genomes project, to enhance the accuracy of CSV calling. Simulations show that Lanc-CSV achieves accuracy comparable to computationally intensive haplotype-based approaches, but with significantly reduced runtime.

The researchers also extended their approach to account for low-coverage sequencing and demonstrated that accurate local ancestry inference can be achieved at low sequencing coverage. Furthermore, they generalized CSVs to sub-continental population-specific variants (sCSVs) and showed that it is possible to determine sub-continental ancestry for short chromosomal segments based on sCSVs. This method has the potential to be particularly useful as sequencing costs decrease and genetic studies sequence more samples, making the tradeoff between computational runtime and accuracy a critical consideration for local ancestry inference.
A new approach to analyzing gene expression data has been developed to identify circadian oscillations in mammalian genes. Previous studies have reported that 10-15% of genes exhibit daily rhythms, regulated by an intrinsic molecular clock. However, statistical analyses have been limited by the small size of datasets and high levels of noise. The new method applies digital signal processing algorithms to each group of genes oscillating in the same phase, combined with statistical tests for periodicity. This approach identifies circadian baseline oscillation in almost 100% of all expressed genes.

The method involves converting single gene profiles into a long continuous stream to reduce noise and enhance the signal. This allows for the identification of patterns of circadian oscillation with confidence. The commonality of oscillation suggests that it is a natural and important feature of all or nearly all biological pathways. Genes that display daily variation in expression level may or may not be linked directly to the circadian molecular clock, but their oscillation will affect the system as a whole.

The new approach has been applied to data from murine liver, and the results show that the amplitude of core circadian genes does not stand out from the majority of expressed genes. The effect of perturbations on the oscillating system depends on the circadian time- and wave-guiding properties of the biological pathways. The study suggests that circadian oscillation in gene expression should be evaluated in any study related to biological pathways, and changes in gene expression caused by mutations or environmental factors should be considered in the context of changes in the amplitude and phase of genetic oscillations.
Researchers used whole-genome re-sequencing to study recombination events in a three-generation pedigree of collared flycatchers. They identified 325 crossover (CO) events at a median resolution of 1.4 kilobases, with 86% of events localized to regions less than 10 kilobases. Crossover rates were higher in males (3.56 centimorgans per megabase) than in females (2.28 centimorgans per megabase) and increased towards chromosome ends in males but not females. Crossover events were non-randomly distributed in the genome, with distinct hotspots and a concentration in genic regions, particularly in promoters and CpG islands.

The researchers also identified 267 non-crossover (NCO) gene conversion events, which were significantly associated with crossover locations. They found a transmission bias in favor of'strong' (G, C) over 'weak' (A, T) alleles at NCO events, providing evidence for GC-biased gene conversion in an avian system. The study's approach can be applied to other species, providing a more comprehensive understanding of the recombination landscape across different organism groups. The findings suggest that recombination events are often concentrated in specific genomic regions, known as hotspots, and that these hotspots may remain relatively stable over time in the absence of an active Prdm9 gene.
Researchers have studied the energy landscapes of repeat-containing proteins, which are composed of near repetitions of 20-40 amino acid stretches. These proteins typically fold into elongated, non-globular architectures, stabilized by interactions within and between repeats, but lacking contacts between distant residues. The inherent symmetries in primary sequence and three-dimensional structure suggest a folding landscape that can be analyzed as a quasi-one-dimensional problem.

A formal Ising-like treatment of the elementary interaction energetics in and between foldons, treated as spin variables, provides a general description of repeat-protein energy landscapes. This approach allows derivation of the overall folding properties of a complete "domain," including stability and cooperativity of the repeating array. The one-dimensional nature of the model implies simple relations for experimental observables, such as folding free-energy and cooperativity of denaturation, which do not apply to globular proteins.

The parameters for the "coarse-grained" description in terms of foldon spin variables can be extracted from detailed folding simulations on perfectly funneled landscapes. A case-study of tetratricopeptide (TPR) repeat proteins illustrates the ideas, and the results are quantitatively related to experimentally observed folding transitions. The study suggests that natural repeat proteins are "poised" at particular ratios of inter- and intra-element interaction energetics, allowing them to undergo structural transitions in physiologically relevant conditions, which may be intrinsically related to their biological functions.
Researchers investigated the role of the stress-regulated transcription factor CHOP in the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), a type of liver cancer. They found that CHOP expression is up-regulated in human HCC tumors and in two mouse models of the disease. Mice lacking the CHOP gene (Chop-null mice) were resistant to chemical-induced liver cancer and exhibited reduced fibrosis, a key risk factor for HCC. Global gene expression profiling revealed that deletion of CHOP reduced basal inflammatory signaling in the liver, suggesting that CHOP promotes inflammation, fibrosis, cell death, and compensatory proliferation. These findings implicate CHOP as a common contributing factor in the development of HCC in various chronic liver diseases, including viral hepatitis, obesity, and alcoholism. The researchers also found that CHOP expression is associated with an agent that causes hepatocyte injury and is upstream of fibrosis activation. In Chop-null mice, gene expression differed from wild-type mice in a way that could account for the greater susceptibility of wild-type mice to fibrosis and oncogenesis, even in the absence of an overt hepatotoxic challenge. These results suggest a stepwise progression from CHOP expression to liver tumors, and understanding the mechanisms by which CHOP promotes oncogenesis may have implications for other cancers beyond HCC.
A systematic review of clinical studies on the treatment of cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) caused by Leishmania aethiopica was conducted to identify potentially efficacious medications. The review included 24 records reporting on 506 treatment episodes of CL, primarily from Ethiopia. The most commonly used treatments were antimonials (201 cases), pentamidine (150 cases), and cryotherapy (103 cases). However, the quality of the studies was poor, with only two small and/or poor-quality randomized controlled trials identified.

Cure rates for cryotherapy ranged from 60-80%, and 69-85% for antimonials. Pentamidine appeared effective against complicated CL, including cases non-responsive to antimonials. However, all studies had methodological limitations. Data on miltefosine, paromomycin, and liposomal amphotericin B were scarce, and only a few studies focused on diffuse CL (DCL). The only potentially effective treatment options for DCL were antimonials with paromomycin in combination or pentamidine, but these have not been properly evaluated.

The evidence base for treating complicated CL due to L. aethiopica is extremely limited. Antimonials remain the most available treatment in Ethiopia, but their efficacy and safety should be better defined. Alternative first-line treatments, such as miltefosine or paromomycin, should be explored. High-quality trials are urgently needed to evaluate treatment options for CL due to L. aethiopica.
Researchers have successfully reconstituted a biochemical oscillator in a laboratory setting using three purified proteins: KaiA, KaiB, and KaiC. This in vitro circadian clockwork displays the key characteristics of natural circadian rhythms, including a self-sustained 24-hour periodicity that is resistant to temperature changes. To understand the biochemical basis of this oscillator, the researchers analyzed the interactions between the three proteins using electron microscopy and native gel electrophoresis. These studies revealed that the proteins form various complexes at different stages of the circadian cycle, with the composition of these complexes changing over time.

A dynamic model was developed to describe the behavior of the in vitro oscillator, which accurately predicts the rhythms of the KaiABC complexes and the phosphorylation of KaiC. The model suggests that the exchange of monomers among KaiC hexamers plays a crucial role in maintaining synchrony among the hexamers and sustaining a high-amplitude oscillation. This was confirmed using fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) experiments, which showed that monomer exchange occurs among KaiC hexamers.

The researchers also used temperature pulses to reset the phase of the KaiABC oscillator, demonstrating that this unique circadian oscillator can be reset by stimuli that are known to entrain natural circadian clocks. Overall, this study provides a detailed understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying the in vitro circadian clockwork, shedding light on the complex interactions between the Kai proteins and their role in generating circadian rhythms.
Researchers investigated the relationship between trial-to-trial brain activity and behavioral performance in a visual stimulus detection task using electrocorticography (ECoG) in patients undergoing invasive brain monitoring for neurosurgical treatment. They found an inverted-U relationship between trial-to-trial brain activity and behavioral output, where hit rate and reaction times were higher and faster when the raw fluctuation in broadband ECoG activity was closer to the across-trial mean. This relationship was observed not only in post-stimulus task-evoked brain activity but also in pre-stimulus spontaneous brain activity, suggesting anticipatory brain dynamics. The findings are consistent with the presence of stochastic noise in the brain and support attractor network theories, which propose that the brain settles into a more confined state space under task performance, with proximity to the targeted trajectory associated with better performance. The study decouples variability reduction from trial-averaged activity, predicting a U- or inverted-U relationship between trial-to-trial brain activity and behavioral performance. The results provide evidence for the existence of an inverted-U function between trial-to-trial fluctuations of brain activity and behavioral performance, which is seldom tested in previous studies.
Researchers studied the mating-type loci in 24 species of Trichosporonales, a group of fungi closely related to the pathogenic Cryptococcus species. They found that the mating-type loci in these species are fused, similar to those in the pathogenic Cryptococci. However, the specific combinations of genes within the fused loci are different between the two groups. This suggests that the fusion of the mating-type loci occurred independently in the Trichosporonales and the pathogenic Cryptococci, a phenomenon known as convergent evolution. Convergent evolution occurs when different species develop similar traits or characteristics in response to similar environmental pressures, despite not being closely related. The researchers also found that the gene content and gene order within the fused mating-type loci are highly conserved in the Trichosporonales, meaning that they have remained relatively unchanged over time. This is in contrast to other fungal groups, where the fused mating-type loci have undergone significant changes. The study provides new insights into the evolution of mating-type loci in fungi and highlights the importance of studying the evolution of genomic regions involved in mating and mating-type determination. The findings also suggest that the mechanisms underlying the evolution of fused mating-type loci may be different between the Trichosporonales and other fungal groups.
Researchers developed a mathematical model to predict the abundance of non-domiciliated Triatoma dimidiata, a vector of Chagas disease, in the Yucatán Peninsula, Mexico. The model was based on two years of field data and accurately predicted the abundance of the vector in the absence and presence of insecticide spraying. The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of different control strategies, including residual insecticide spraying, insect screens, and bednets.

The results showed that pyrethroid spraying was effective in reducing the abundance of non-domiciliated vectors when applied at a dose of 50 mg/m2 over a two-month period matching the immigration season. However, larger doses or more frequent interventions did not improve the reduction in bug abundance, and it decreased drastically when the timing or frequency of intervention was altered. In contrast, the use of insect screens consistently reduced bug abundance proportionally to the reduction of the vector immigration rate.

The study found that control of non-domiciliated vectors through insecticide spraying is challenging due to the need for yearly application and accurate understanding of the temporal pattern of immigration. Insect screens, on the other hand, appear to offer an effective and sustainable alternative for controlling non-domiciliated vectors. The findings suggest that insect screens may be a valuable component of multi-disease interventions for the integrated control of neglected vector-borne diseases.
Feather patterning in avian skin is a complex process that relies on the interaction of multiple signaling pathways and cell density waves. During development, feathers first appear along the dorsal midline as a row, with new feather buds added sequentially in a spreading wave. Research has shown that this patterning is achieved through a coordinated reaction-diffusion-taxis system involving fibroblast growth factor (FGF) and bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signaling, as well as mesenchymal cell movement. This system is partly mechanochemical, with mechanical-chemical integration occurring through a positive feedback loop centered on FGF20, which induces cell aggregation and compresses the epidermis to intensify FGF20 expression.

The traveling wave of feather formation is imposed by expanding expression of Ectodysplasin A (EDA), which initiates the expression of FGF20. The EDA wave spreads across a mesenchymal cell density gradient, triggering pattern formation by lowering the threshold of mesenchymal cells required to begin forming a feather bud. In flightless birds, such as the emu and ostrich, the feather patterning system is disrupted, resulting in the loss of the characteristic feather array. However, the ostrich retains the tract arrangement characteristic of birds in general, but lays down feather primordia without a wave, similar to the process of hair follicle formation in mammalian embryos. The embryonic emu skin lacks sufficient cells to enact feather formation, causing failure of tract formation, and instead gains feather primordia through a later process.
A rapid systematic review of published evidence on the presence of filoviruses in body fluids of infected people and survivors was conducted. The review aimed to determine which body fluids are infectious and when they pose a risk to humans. A total of 6831 unique articles were found, and 33 studies were eligible for inclusion. The review found that most body fluid types had insufficient patients to draw strong conclusions, and the prevalence of positivity was highly variable. Body fluids taken more than 16 days after the onset of illness were usually negative. Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) tests for filovirus RNA gave positive results about four times more often than tissue culture tests. Filovirus was reported in most types of body fluid, but not in every sample from every confirmed patient. Apart from semen, most non-blood, RT-PCR-positive samples are likely to be culture-negative and possibly of low infectious risk. Contact with blood and blood-stained body fluids remains the major risk for disease transmission due to the known high viral loads in blood. The review highlights the need for further research to determine the relative infectiousness of various body fluids during and after illness.
Researchers have developed a new mathematical model, called the fractional leaky integrate-and-fire model, to describe the complex dynamics of neuronal activity in the brain. This model takes into account the correlations between different membrane conductances, which can lead to power-law behavior in the voltage trace of neurons. The model uses a fractional derivative, which is a non-local process that integrates a weighted voltage trace, or memory trace, to determine the value of the variable. This approach allows the model to capture the non-Markovian process of neuronal activity, which cannot be described by a single time constant.

The fractional model can reproduce the upward and downward spike adaptations found in experimental studies of neocortical pyramidal cells and tectal neurons. By varying the exponent of the fractional derivative, the model can produce spikes with longer first-spike latency and high inter-spike variability, with a power-law distribution. The model also generates reliable spike patterns in response to noisy input, and its spiking activity deviates from the Markovian model, reflecting the temporal accumulated intrinsic membrane dynamics that affect the response of the neuron to external stimulation. The fractional model provides a unified mathematical and computational framework for describing power-law dynamics and long-range correlations in neuronal activity, and can capture relationships between the distribution of conductances that are complicated to model using explicit techniques.
Researchers investigated the role of superoxide dismutases (SODs) in the pathogenesis of Paracoccidioides spp., a fungus that causes paracoccidioidomycosis. The study identified six SOD isoforms encoded by the Paracoccidioides genome and analyzed their expression levels in different stages of the fungus's life cycle, including yeast and mycelia cells, as well as during interaction with host effector cells. The results showed that two SOD isoforms, PbSOD1 and PbSOD3, were highly expressed during the transition from yeast to mycelia, exposure to oxidative agents, and interaction with phagocytic cells. This suggests that these proteins play a crucial role in combating superoxide radicals generated during the host-pathogen interaction. Using knockdown strains, the researchers demonstrated that PbSOD1 and PbSOD3 are involved in the fungus's response to oxidative stress and host effector cells. Protein sequence analysis and functional analysis of knockdown strains indicated that PbSOD3 is linked to extracellular activity, while PbSOD1 is related to intracellular requirements of the fungus. The study suggests that Paracoccidioides actively responds to endogenously generated radicals and counteracts the oxidative burst of immune cells by inducing the expression of SOD isoforms. The findings provide new insights into the antioxidant response of Paracoccidioides and highlight the importance of SODs in its pathogenesis.
A recent study investigated the relationship between intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) and chaperone binding in various species, including E. coli, S. cerevisiae, and metazoa. Contrary to the expectation that IDPs would be preferentially associated with chaperones to protect against proteolysis, the study found that predicted disorder negatively correlates with chaperone binding. This means that IDPs tend to avoid binding to chaperones in vivo. The analysis of high-throughput interaction data revealed that proteins with predicted disorder are less likely to bind chaperones compared to those with ordered structures.

The study also found that the presence of ordered domains, such as Pfam domains, is associated with a preference for chaperone binding, suggesting that chaperones are primarily required for the folding of globular proteins. In contrast, IDPs that bind chaperones tend to bind other proteins as well, indicating that chaperone binding may facilitate the assembly of IDPs with their partners rather than assisting in their folding. This conclusion is supported by the observation that IDPs that bind chaperones are more likely to bind other proteins compared to ordered proteins. The study's findings have implications for our understanding of the role of chaperones in the cell and the behavior of IDPs, which are known to be sensitive to proteolysis in vitro but show no enhanced degradation rates in vivo.
Researchers have investigated the role of the Spalt transcription factors, encoded by the Drosophila genes spalt major (salm) and spalt-related (salr), in the development of the wing imaginal disc. These transcription factors are regulated by the Decapentaplegic (Dpp) signaling pathway and are essential for cell survival and proliferation in the central region of the wing disc, as well as vein patterning in the lateral regions. To understand the genetic control of wing growth and patterning, the researchers identified direct Salm and Salr target genes by comparing the expression profile of salm/salr knockdown wing discs with control discs using microarray experiments. In situ hybridization revealed a complex transcription landscape regulated by the Spalt proteins, including both activated and repressed genes. Candidate Salm/Salr target genes were identified, and loss-of-function phenotypic analysis showed that some of these genes are required for wing growth and patterning. This study provides new insights into the genetic hierarchy acting downstream of Dpp signaling in the wing disc and sheds light on the mechanisms by which Spalt proteins regulate transcription. The identification of Salm/Salr target genes opens a new avenue to reconstruct the genetic structure of the wing, linking the activity of the Dpp pathway to the development of this epithelial tissue. The study reveals an unsuspected complexity in the transcriptional landscape regulated by Salm/Salr, consisting of batteries of activated and repressed genes.
Researchers have identified a key regulator of centriole duplication in the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans). Centrioles are essential components of centrosomes, which are crucial for cell division. Abnormalities in centriole number have been linked to tumorigenesis and microcephaly in humans. The C. elegans protein ZYG-1, a homolog of the human protein Plk4, is required for centriole duplication. However, the regulation of ZYG-1 levels was not fully understood.

The study found that two protein phosphatase 1 (PP1) orthologs, GSP-1 and GSP-2, and their regulators I-2SZY-2 and SDS-22, play a crucial role in regulating ZYG-1 levels. Down-regulation of PP1 activity, either directly or through mutations in szy-2 or sds-22, can rescue the loss of centriole duplication associated with a zyg-1 hypomorphic allele. This is achieved through an increase in ZYG-1 levels, indicating that PP1 normally regulates ZYG-1 through a post-translational mechanism.

Moderate inhibition of PP1 activity can restore centriole duplication in a zyg-1 mutant, but strong inhibition of PP1 in a wild-type background leads to centriole amplification, resulting in the production of more than one daughter centriole. The study defines a new pathway that limits the number of daughter centrioles produced each cycle. The findings suggest that PP1 is a critical regulator of centriole duplication and that modulating PP1 activity may impact centriole number.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in an environmentally protected area (EPA) in southeastern Brazil to investigate visceral leishmaniasis (VL) transmission. The study focused on the municipality of Campinas, where the first autochthonous case of VL in a dog was reported in 2009. Since then, disease transmission has been restricted to dogs living in two geographically contiguous condominiums within the EPA. The study aimed to investigate Leishmania spp. infection in domestic dogs, wild mammals, and sand flies using molecular tools and serological techniques. Canine seroprevalences of 1.5% and 1.2% were observed in 2013 and 2015, respectively. Six insect species, confirmed or suspected vectors or potential transmitters of Leishmania, were identified, including Lutzomyia longipalpis, the main vector of Leishmania infantum in Brazil. Natural infection by L. (L.) infantum was recorded in one Expapillata firmatoi specimen and two Pintomyia monticola, as well as in two white-eared opossums (Didelphis albiventris), a known reservoir of VL. The study found that the EPA, inhabited by humans, has an active VL focus, and the risk of establishing and maintaining disease transmission foci in similar scenarios is evident.
The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)-encoded microRNA miR-BART9 has been found to play a significant role in promoting tumor metastasis in nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), a highly metastatic type of cancer frequently reported in South Asia. Research has shown that miR-BART9 is highly expressed in EBV-positive NPC tissues and targets the E-cadherin protein, which is crucial for maintaining cell-cell junctions and the epithelial phenotype. By inhibiting E-cadherin, miR-BART9 induces a mesenchymal-like phenotype in NPC cells, leading to enhanced migration and invasiveness. This prometastatic activity was observed both in vitro and in vivo, indicating that miR-BART9 contributes to the aggressive behavior of NPC tumor cells. Computational analysis revealed that miR-BART9 shares a "seed sequence" with the miR-200 family, which is down-modulated in NPC tumors, suggesting a potential link between miR-BART9 and the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) process. The study's findings suggest that miR-BART9 is a significant viral contributor to the migratory and invasive capability of EBV-infected tumor cells, and high levels of miR-BART9 in EBV-positive NPC cells may contribute to the aggressiveness of tumor cells.
A new command-line tool called ggsashimi has been developed for visualizing splicing events across multiple samples. This tool creates sashimi plots for individual RNA-seq experiments as well as aggregated plots for groups of experiments. Unlike existing versions of sashimi plot-generating programs, ggsashimi uses popular bioinformatics file formats, is annotation-independent, and allows for the visualization of splicing events in large genomic regions by scaling down genomic segments between splice sites. The tool is implemented in Python and generates R code for plotting.

The development of ggsashimi aims to address the limitations of current sashimi plot implementations, which are often annotation-dependent and not dynamically integrated in common genome browsers. Visualizing splicing events can be challenging due to the non-contiguous nature of splice sites on the genome sequence, which can be tens or hundreds of kilobases apart.

Ggsashimi has been compared to the sashimi-plot built-in available within the Integrative Genomics Viewer (IGV) browser. The results show that ggsashimi's aggregation of samples and shrinkage of intron lengths enhance the visualization of splicing events. The ggsashimi tool is freely available at https://github.com/guigolab/ggsashimi.
Researchers have developed a new model to predict and align cis-regulatory modules (CRMs) across different species. CRMs are non-coding DNA sequences that regulate gene expression by binding to transcription factors. The new model, called EMMA (Evolutionary Model-based cis-regulatory Module Analysis), uses a probabilistic approach to account for the evolution of functional transcription factor binding sites (TFBSs) and background sequences. Unlike existing models, EMMA explicitly treats the evolution of TFBSs, including gains and losses, which is a crucial aspect of regulatory sequence evolution.

The model is based on a statistical alignment method that uses conserved binding sites to improve alignment accuracy. EMMA's CRM prediction method addresses the uncertainties of binding site annotations and sequence alignment by using a probabilistic framework. In simulated and real data, EMMA outperformed several state-of-the-art methods in aligning and predicting CRMs.

The researchers applied EMMA to study the conservation of binding sites in genome-wide binding data of key transcription factors in Drosophila blastoderm. They found that factor-bound sequences are under strong evolutionary constraints, even if their neighboring genes are not expressed in the blastoderm. Additionally, binding sites in distal regions (relative to transcription start sites) tend to be more conserved than those in proximal regions. The EMMA software is available for use in various biological contexts.
Researchers have investigated the role of the piRNA (PIWI-interacting RNA) pathway in genome maintenance and telomere protection in Drosophila. The piRNA pathway is known to silence transposons in the germline, but its functions during development were unclear. Mutations in the piRNA pathway genes armi, aub, ago3, and rhi were found to lead to extensive fragmentation of the zygotic genome during embryonic divisions. Additionally, mutations in aub and armi resulted in defects in telomere resolution during meiosis and embryonic divisions. Chromatin immunoprecipitation studies showed that aub and armi mutations disrupted telomere binding of HOAP, a component of the telomere protection complex, and reduced expression of a subpopulation of 19- to 22-nt telomere-specific piRNAs. In contrast, mutations in rhi and ago3 did not block HOAP binding or production of these piRNAs. These findings suggest that the piRNA pathway has distinct functions in genome maintenance and telomere protection. The aub, armi, rhi, and ago3 genes silence transposons and maintain chromosome integrity during embryonic divisions, while aub and armi have an additional function in assembling the telomere protection complex. The study reveals a novel function for a subset of piRNA genes in telomere protection and suggests that this process is directed by a subpopulation of 19-22 nt piRNAs.
A new species of the Ebola virus, known as Bundibugyo ebolavirus, has been identified as the cause of a hemorrhagic fever outbreak in western Uganda. The outbreak, which occurred in November 2007, resulted in 149 suspected cases and 37 deaths, with a case fatality rate of approximately 36%. This new virus is most closely related to the Côte d'Ivoire ebolavirus, despite being found in a geographically distant location. The discovery of Bundibugyo ebolavirus has significant implications for the development of diagnostic assays, antivirals, and vaccines against Ebola hemorrhagic fever. The virus is distinct from previously recognized ebolaviruses, such as Zaire and Sudan ebolaviruses, which have case fatality rates ranging from 53% to 90%. The lower case fatality rate associated with Bundibugyo ebolavirus suggests that it may have different antigenic and pathogenic properties compared to other ebolaviruses. To better understand the characteristics of this new virus, further studies are needed, including pathogenicity studies in non-human primates and cross-protection studies to assess the effectiveness of existing vaccines against Bundibugyo ebolavirus. The rapid identification and isolation of Ebola cases during the outbreak were facilitated by the transfer of diagnostic assays to the Uganda Virus Research Institute, allowing for efficient control of the outbreak.
Researchers analyzed a large dataset of 648 Alzheimer's Disease (AD) patients with an average follow-up time of 4.78 years to understand the progression of the disease. They used the Global Deterioration Scale (GDS) and Functional Assessment Staging procedure (FAST) to categorize the patients into seven stages of AD, from normal aging to severe dementia. The study found that the durations of GDS/FAST stages 4-6 varied significantly among patients, with standard deviations comparable to their mean values. This indicates a high degree of heterogeneity in the progression of AD, suggesting that patients may belong to different subgroups with distinct patterns of decline.

The study's findings are consistent with previous reports of variability in AD progression rates, which have been attributed to a combination of factors. The researchers used a 23-year longitudinal dataset, providing a comprehensive representation of patients at GDS/FAST stages 4-7 of AD. The FAST procedure, which describes a continuum of 16 stages and substages from normality to severe dementia, was used in conjunction with the GDS. The study's results have implications for evaluating the results of clinical studies and understanding the underlying reasons for the variability in AD progression rates. The findings suggest that AD is a heterogeneous disease, with different subgroups of patients exhibiting distinct patterns of cognitive and functional decline.
Researchers have extended a previous study on adult neurogenesis in a simplified hippocampal memory model to include realistic, spatially driven input firing patterns in the form of grid cells in the entorhinal cortex. The model compared three adaptation strategies: conventional synaptic plasticity, neuronal turnover, and additive neurogenesis. The results confirmed that additive neurogenesis is a superior adaptation strategy, allowing the network to respond to changes in input statistics while preserving representations of earlier environments.

The study found that a more biologically plausible neurogenesis rule, incorporating cell death and enhanced plasticity of new granule cells, outperformed the individual strategies. This adaptation rule can be tailored to maximize network performance as a short- or long-term memory store. The researchers also examined the time course of adult neurogenesis over an animal's lifetime under different hypothetical rearing conditions, predicting distinct growth profiles that could be tested experimentally.

The model demonstrated that place cells can emerge and refine in a realistic manner as a result of the sparsification performed by the dentate gyrus layer. The study suggests that additive neurogenesis endows the network with the ability to adapt in a way not possible with conventional plasticity or neuronal turnover, providing a theoretical argument for why additive neurogenesis should be observed in the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus.
In bloodstream African trypanosomes, cytosolic peroxidases play a crucial role in protecting the lysosome from iron-mediated membrane damage. The parasites express three virtually identical non-selenium glutathione peroxidase-type enzymes, Px I, Px II, and Px III, which detoxify lipid-derived hydroperoxides. Research has shown that parasites lacking Px I and Px II undergo rapid lipid peroxidation and cell lysis, whereas those lacking Px III display only a weak and transient proliferation defect. Supplementing the medium with the antioxidant Trolox rescues the phenotype of Px I and Px II knockout parasites.

The study found that the lysosome is the primary site of oxidative damage in bloodstream trypanosomes. Feeding Px I and Px II knockout parasites with Alexa Fluor-conjugated dextran or LysoTracker in the presence of Trolox yielded a discrete lysosomal staining, which became progressively spread over the whole cell body and was completely lost upon withdrawal of the antioxidant. Supplementing the medium with iron or transferrin induced lysis of the Px I and Px II knockout cells, while the iron chelator deferoxamine and apo-transferrin attenuated lysis.

Immunofluorescence microscopy revealed that disintegration of the lysosome precedes mitochondrial damage. In vivo experiments confirmed the negligible role of the mitochondrial peroxidase, as mice infected with Px III knockout cells displayed only a slightly delayed disease development compared to wild-type parasites. The study demonstrates that cytosolic trypanothione/tryparedoxin-dependent peroxidases protect the lysosome from iron-induced membrane peroxidation, which is closely linked to the high endocytic rate and distinct iron acquisition mechanisms of the infective stage of T. brucei.
Researchers have inactivated the Pmel gene in mice to study its role in melanosome shape and pigmentation. Melanosomes are organelles in pigment cells where eumelanin, a type of melanin, is produced. The Pmel gene encodes an amyloidogenic protein that forms intralumenal fibrils within melanosomes. The study found that mice lacking the Pmel gene (Pmel−/−) have spherical melanosomes instead of the typical oblong shape found in wild-type animals. This change in shape was observed in various types of melanocytes, including skin-derived melanocytes, retinal pigment epithelium cells, and uveal melanocytes.

The inactivation of Pmel had a mild effect on the coat color phenotype, with the most noticeable effect observed in mice carrying the brown/Tyrp1 mutation. The study suggests that previously described alleles in vertebrates with more striking effects on pigmentation may be dominant-negative mutations. Despite the mild effect on visible pigmentation, the Pmel knockout mutation led to a substantial reduction in eumelanin content in hair, indicating that PMEL plays a critical role in maintaining efficient epidermal pigmentation. The study demonstrates that PMEL is essential for the normal development of rod-shaped melanosomes in eumelanin-producing melanocytes, but not for the general survival of pigment cells in several tissues.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of environmental methods for dengue vector control. The review included 19 studies that met the eligibility criteria, with 16 contributing data to the meta-analysis. The methods evaluated were container covers with and without insecticides, waste management and clean-up campaigns, and elimination of breeding sites. Study quality was highest for container covers with insecticides, followed by waste management without direct garbage collection and elimination of breeding places.

The meta-analysis showed a weak effect of the interventions on larval populations, with no obvious differences between the results of each individual method. However, container covers without insecticides and waste management with direct garbage collection achieved the strongest reductions in the Breteau index (BI), a measure of mosquito breeding sites. In contrast, container covers with insecticides and elimination of breeding places showed the strongest effects on the pupae per person index (PPI), a measure of mosquito pupae density.

Each of the investigated environmental methods showed some effectiveness in reducing larval and pupal densities of Aedes sp. mosquitoes. However, the quality of the studies was a major issue, with most assessed as low or medium quality. The results suggest that environmental interventions can be effective in controlling the immature stages of Aedes sp. mosquitoes, but more comparable high-quality studies are needed to strengthen the evidence.
Researchers have identified small molecules that selectively stall protein synthesis by the ribosome, which could lead to new therapeutic strategies for treating diseases. One such compound, PF-06378503 (PF8503), inhibits the translation of PCSK9, a major regulator of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and reduces LDL cholesterol in preclinical models. However, the effects of PF8503 on cell physiology and ribosome quality control pathways are not well understood. To investigate this, a genome-wide CRISPRi screen was conducted to identify proteins and pathways that modulate cell growth in the presence of high doses of PF8503. The screen revealed that the ubiquitin binding protein ASCC2 and helicase ASCC3 bind to the ribosome and protect cells from the toxic effects of PF8503. In contrast, translation quality control proteins Pelota (PELO) and HBS1L sensitize cells to PF8503 treatment. Genetic interaction experiments showed that ASCC3 acts together with ASCC2 and functions downstream of HBS1L. These findings provide new insights into the selectivity of compounds that stall human translation and could aid in the development of next-generation selective translation stalling compounds to treat disease.
Researchers have discovered a novel mechanism by which the Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) promotes widespread destruction of cellular messenger RNA (mRNA) to evade immune detection and block host gene expression. The viral protein SOX is responsible for this phenotype, but its mechanism of action was previously unknown. The study found that SOX stimulates cellular transcriptome turnover through a unique process involving aberrant polyadenylation, where transcripts in SOX-expressing cells exhibit extended poly(A) polymerase II-generated poly(A) tails and polyadenylation-linked mRNA turnover. This process correlates with SOX's RNA turnover function, and inhibiting poly(A) tail formation blocks SOX activity. Nuclear and cytoplasmic poly(A) binding proteins are critical cellular cofactors for SOX function, with the latter undergoing striking nuclear relocalization by SOX. The study suggests that SOX-induced mRNA turnover represents a novel mechanism of host shutoff and a new model system to study the regulation of poly(A) tail-stimulated mRNA turnover in mammalian cells. The findings also reveal a link between polyadenylation and RNA surveillance and turnover, which may have implications for understanding the regulation of gene expression in higher eukaryotes.
Researchers investigated the role of type III interferon (IFNλ) in the innate immune response to bacterial pathogens, specifically Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. They found that these bacteria induce significant production of IFNλ in the lung, which is essential for host defense. Mice lacking the IFNλ receptor (IL-28R) showed improved clearance of bacteria and reduced lung pathology compared to wild-type mice. This was associated with a reduced ratio of pro-inflammatory to anti-inflammatory cytokines in the airway. In human epithelial cells, IFNλ inhibited the microRNA miR-21, leading to upregulation of the protein PDCD4, which promotes inflammatory signaling. In vivo, miR-21 was reduced and PDCD4 was increased in the lungs of wild-type mice, but not in IL-28R null mice. Infection of PDCD4 null mice with S. aureus resulted in improved clearance, reduced pathology, and reduced inflammatory cytokine production. These findings suggest that IFNλ promotes inflammation by inhibiting miR-21 regulation of PDCD4 during bacterial pneumonia. The study highlights the conserved role of IFNλ and PDCD4 in the response to airway pathogens, and suggests that inhibiting IL-28R-dependent signaling may reduce lung inflammation and improve bacterial clearance.
A retrospective study was conducted on 781 patients with advanced stage-2 Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) admitted to the National Reference Center for Human African Trypanosomiasis in the Democratic Republic of Congo between 1989 and 2012. The study aimed to investigate mortality trends and risk factors associated with the disease. The outcome variable was death, and predictors included age, gender, duration of disease, location of trypanosomes in body fluids, cytorachy, protidorachy, clinical status on admission, and treatment regimen.

The study found that death proportions varied significantly across different treatment regimens: 17.2% in the standard melarsoprol schedule, 12.1% in the short schedule melarsoprol, 5.4% in the first-line eflornithine regimen, 9.1% in the NECT treatment regimen, and 36% in the group treated with eflornithine due to severe clinical status. After adjusting for treatment, the study identified significant predictors of death, including clinical dysfunction on admission, high protidorachy, presence of parasites in the cerebrospinal fluid, and high cytorachy.

A multivariable analysis within treatment groups retained clinical status on admission and high protidorachy as significant predictors of death. The study suggests that the algorithm used for initial clinical status assessment may serve as a basis for developing standardized assessment tools for HAT management and epidemiological reporting. The findings highlight the importance of clinical manifestations in disease severity assessment and the need for an objective test to evaluate HAT clinical severity.
Researchers have developed a new computer vision pipeline to study the effects of isolation on social interaction dynamics in Drosophila melanogaster, a common model organism for studying social behavior. The pipeline uses a novel imaging arena and improved tracking algorithm to follow a large number of flies simultaneously, allowing for the automatic classification of touch and graph-based social network analysis. This enabled the researchers to quantify changes in the social network in response to prior social isolation.

The study found that isolation significantly and swiftly enhanced individual and local social network parameters depicting near-neighbor relationships. The researchers also explored the genome-wide molecular correlates of these behavioral changes and found that while behavior changed throughout the six days of isolation, gene expression alterations occurred largely on day one. These changes were mostly in metabolic genes, and the researchers verified the metabolic changes by showing an increase in lipid content in isolated flies.

The results suggest that isolation has a profound impact on social network dynamics, metabolic gene expression, and animal physiology in Drosophila. The study also found that behavioral alterations were long-lasting, while changes in gene expression levels were transient. One of the individual fly parameters that changed early and persistently was walking distance. The findings of this study provide new insights into the effects of isolation on social behavior and highlight the potential of Drosophila as a model organism for studying social behavior and its underlying mechanisms.
A clinical pilot study was conducted in rural Bangladesh to evaluate the impact of a smartphone adaptation of the World Health Organization (WHO) diarrheal disease management guidelines. The study aimed to improve adherence to evidence-based guidelines in resource-limited settings. A smartphone-based decision-support tool, including a modality for age-based weight estimation, was developed and evaluated in a district and sub-district hospital during the 2015 cholera season. The study consisted of a 6-week pre-intervention and 6-week intervention period, with a 10-day post-discharge follow-up. A total of 841 patients were enrolled, and the primary outcome was adherence to guidelines for prescriptions of intravenous fluids, antibiotics, and zinc.

Results showed that during the intervention, the proportion of prescriptions for intravenous fluids decreased at both hospitals, with risk ratios of 0.5 and 0.2, respectively. When IV fluids were prescribed, the volume better adhered to recommendations. The proportion of prescriptions for the recommended antibiotic azithromycin increased, while prescriptions for other antibiotics decreased. Zinc adherence also increased. These findings demonstrate that a smartphone-based tool can improve guideline adherence. The study identified opportunities to improve clinical care, including better assessment, weight estimation, and fluid/antibiotic selection. The results support the hypothesis that technology-enabled decision-support tools can promote evidence-based practice in resource-limited settings.
Scientists have long struggled to predict how changes in temperature will affect the dynamics of host-parasite interactions, which are crucial for understanding the impact of climate change on disease prevalence and severity. To address this challenge, researchers developed a mathematical model that incorporates the metabolic theory of ecology (MTE) to describe the temperature dependencies of host and parasite traits. The model was tested using experimental data from Daphnia magna, a small crustacean, and its natural parasite, Ordospora colligata.

The study found that the MTE-based model effectively predicted host survival, parasite growth, and the cost of infection across a range of temperatures, using fewer parameters than traditional models. The results demonstrate the potential of linking simple metabolic models with a mechanistic host-parasite framework to predict temperature responses of parasite population dynamics at the within-host level. This approach provides a valuable tool for understanding the impacts of temperature changes on disease, as it allows for the integration of distinct thermal dependencies for various host and parasite traits.

The study's findings suggest that the MTE-based model can be used to estimate the net effect of temperature changes on disease prevalence and severity. The simplicity and generality of this framework make it a promising approach for predicting the outcomes and consequences of infections for hosts and parasites in the face of climate change.
Researchers have investigated the role of GABAergic interneurons in shaping the activity of excitatory pyramidal cells (PCs) in the brain. Specifically, they focused on the interplay between three types of interneurons: parvalbumin- (PV), somatostatin- (SOM), and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP)-expressing interneurons. These interneurons play a crucial role in controlling the distribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition onto PCs, which is essential for neuronal information processing.

The study proposes a functional role for a network motif consisting of PV, SOM, and VIP interneurons, which acts as an amplifier that translates weak inputs onto VIP cells into large changes in the somato-dendritic distribution of inhibition onto PCs. This amplification is achieved through mutual inhibition between SOM and VIP neurons, which allows for switch-like spatial shifts of somato-dendritic inhibition.

The researchers used a computational model to demonstrate that the neuronal and synaptic properties of the circuit support this hypothesis. They also showed that the SOM-VIP motif allows transient inputs to persistently switch the circuit between two processing modes, in which top-down inputs onto apical dendrites of PCs are either integrated or cancelled. The study highlights the importance of understanding the functional roles of these interneuron classes and their individual characteristics in controlling different input streams and information processing modes.
Microbiome-wide association studies (MWAS) are used to link specific microbes to host phenotypes, such as disease. However, these studies can produce spurious associations due to indirect effects of microbial interactions. Researchers found that realistic microbial interactions can generate a large number of indirect associations that do not provide mechanistic insight. To address this issue, a method called Direct Association Analysis (DAA) was developed using techniques from statistical physics. This method removes indirect associations and was applied to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The results showed that only a small subset of associations is directly linked to the disease. Direct associations had a higher accuracy in separating cases from controls and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate production, and the brain-gut axis as important factors in IBD. The study suggests that many previously reported associations between microbiota and IBD could be indirect. The researchers estimated the relative contribution of indirect associations to MWAS and showed how to isolate direct from indirect associations. They found that interspecific interactions are strong enough to generate detectable changes in the abundance of many microbes not directly linked to host phenotype. The study highlights the importance of accounting for microbial interactions in MWAS to avoid spurious associations and gain a better understanding of the relationship between microbiota and host phenotypes.
Researchers compared the effectiveness of two Wolbachia infection models, stable and transient, in blocking the replication and transmission of dengue and West Nile viruses in Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. Wolbachia is a bacterium that can be introduced into mosquitoes to prevent the spread of diseases such as dengue and Zika. The study found that Wolbachia had a similar blocking effect on both stable and transient models of infection, but the magnitude of the blocking effect was lower in mosquitoes that were transiently infected with Wolbachia. The researchers also found no evidence that Wolbachia enhanced the infection of either dengue or West Nile virus in Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. This suggests that Wolbachia could be a safe and effective means of restricting the transmission of these viruses. The study used two types of Wolbachia infection models: stable transinfected and transiently infected mosquitoes. Stable transinfected mosquitoes have Wolbachia that is inherited by their offspring, while transiently infected mosquitoes have Wolbachia that is not passed on to their offspring. The researchers found that the density of Wolbachia in transiently infected mosquitoes was lower than in stable infected mosquitoes, which may explain why the blocking effect was less effective in transiently infected mosquitoes. The study provides new insights into the interaction between Wolbachia, its host, and disease-causing pathogens, and has implications for the use of Wolbachia as a tool for controlling the spread of diseases.
Researchers investigated the biogenesis, structure, and composition of the ciliary doublet region and Inversin compartment (InvC) in the roundworm Caenorhabditis elegans. They found that the InvC is conserved and distinct from the doublet region, and that the genes nphp-2, arl-13, klp-11, and unc-119 are redundantly required for ciliogenesis. These genes can be sorted into two modules: nphp-2+klp-11 and arl-13+unc-119, which are antagonized by the hdac-6 deacetylase. The genes in this network modulate the sizes of the NPHP-2 InvC and ARL-13 doublet region. Glutamylation, a tubulin post-translational modification, is not required for ciliary targeting of InvC and doublet region components, but is modulated by nphp-2, arl-13, and unc-119. The ciliary targeting and restricted localization of NPHP-2, ARL-13, and UNC-119 do not require TZ-, doublet region, and InvC-associated genes. NPHP-2 requires its calcium binding EF hand domain for targeting to the InvC. The study concludes that the C. elegans InvC is distinct from the doublet region, and that components in these two regions interact to regulate ciliogenesis via cilia placement, ciliary microtubule ultrastructure, and protein localization.
Researchers have discovered that the protein Scribble plays a crucial role in the development and regeneration of myelin in the central nervous system (CNS). Myelin is a fatty substance that surrounds nerve fibers and facilitates the transmission of electrical signals. Oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for producing myelin in the CNS, undergo significant changes in shape to initiate and form myelin sheaths. The study found that Scribble is expressed throughout oligodendroglial development and is up-regulated in mature oligodendrocytes, where it is localized to both developing and mature CNS myelin sheaths.

Knockdown of Scribble expression in cultured oligodendroglia resulted in disrupted morphology and myelination initiation. Similarly, conditional elimination of Scribble in the myelinating glia of transgenic mice disrupted myelin initiation in the CNS, both during development and following focal demyelination. Scribble was also found to negatively regulate myelin thickness and suppress the extracellular signal-related kinase (ERK)/mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAP) kinase pathway. Furthermore, Scribble localized to non-compact myelin flanking the node of Ranvier, where it is required for paranodal axo-glial adhesion.

These findings demonstrate that Scribble is essential for myelination and remyelination in the CNS. The study suggests that Scribble's function is compartmentalized through interactions with different protein complexes at sites of radial or longitudinal growth, and that it plays a critical role in regulating cell signaling and axo-glial adhesion.
A novel peptide haemolysin, Listeriolysin S, has been identified in a subset of Lineage I Listeria monocytogenes strains, which are responsible for the majority of listeriosis outbreaks. Listeriolysin S is a cytotoxic and haemolytic factor that contributes to the virulence of the pathogen, as demonstrated in murine- and human polymorphonuclear neutrophil-based studies. This discovery expands the family of modified virulence peptides (MVPs) associated with Gram-positive pathogens, which were previously thought to be exclusive to Streptococcus species. The genetic basis for the enhanced virulence of a proportion of Lineage I L. monocytogenes strains may have been revealed through the identification of the Listeriolysin S gene cluster. In silico analysis suggests that similar gene clusters encoding SLS-like factors are present in other notorious Gram-positive pathogens, including Staphylococcus aureus and Clostridium botulinum. The biosynthetic enzymes responsible for Listeriolysin S production, SagBCD, function similarly to those involved in the production of microcin B17, a related virulence factor. The identification of Listeriolysin S and its associated gene cluster provides new insights into the pathogenesis of L. monocytogenes and highlights the importance of MVPs in the virulence of Gram-positive pathogens.
Researchers investigated the role of interleukin-17 (IL-17) and matrix metalloprotease-9 (MMP-9) in the formation of mycetoma granulomas, a type of granulomatous inflammatory disease caused by fungi or bacteria. Mycetoma granulomas are characterized by the presence of macroscopic structures called grains, surrounded by a massive inflammatory reaction. The study aimed to determine the expression levels of IL-17 and MMP-9 in mycetoma lesions and their correlation with the severity of the disease.

The study analyzed surgical biopsies from 100 patients with confirmed mycetoma and found that IL-17 was mainly expressed in Zones I and II, while MMP-9 was detected mainly in Zones II and III. MMP-9 expression was higher in biopsies from Actinomadura pelletierii and Streptomyces somaliensis compared to Madurella mycetomatis biopsies. The study also found a direct correlation between IL-17 and MMP-9 expression levels (p = 0.001) and a significant association between MMP-9 levels and disease duration (p < 0.001).

The results suggest that IL-17 and MMP-9 are present in mycetoma granulomas and that their expression levels are correlated with the severity of the disease.
